You will be provided with a Moodle discussion forum post that includes the post title and post description. Moodle is a free and open-source learning management system (LMS) used by schools, universities, and workplaces to create online courses and manage learning activities.
Your task is to classify if the provided discussion forum post is a feature request or not for Moodle. A feature request is a post where the user asks for new functionality, missing functionality (e.g., features available in other apps), new content, or changes/improvements to existing features in future releases. Posts that are not feature requests include: bug reports, troubleshooting questions, usage questions, configuration issues, announcements, or general discussions.

If the forum post is not a feature request, return NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. Use the title of the post and the description of the post to make the assessment.

Post title: Extracting Large Logs
Post description: Hi We use Moodle for commercial purposes, and our company is interested in site activity and not just learning activities . We have been using the log to track and analyse login data, guest activity, and more. Unfortunately, our log has grown too large to extract, and I get a " Hmmm... cant reach this site " in my browser every time I try to extract a log. Is there a way or a trick to extract large logs, without the browser giving up? Or Partner does not have any suggestions. Best regards, Lene Marie

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Statistics report processing start time?
Post description: The documentation for Moodle's Statistics report says: TIP: Set the stats processing to start an hour before your automated course backups are scheduled to start, then set the maximum runtime to 1 hour. This ensures that stats are not being processed at the same time as course backups are being made. However, the settings in Server » Statistics don't seem to include any settings related to specifying when the statistics processing will run (only how long it will run for and the amount of data to process). Is this something that it is now no longer necessary to set explicitly? (We are running Moodle 4.5)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Generating Graphical Reports & Integrating Looker Studio with Moodle Workplace
Post description: Hello everyone, We are using Moodle Workplace to deliver onboarding learning for our customers, and we currently have 600+ tenants set up. While the built-in Moodle reports are functional, most of them are very tabular in format , which makes it challenging to present insights clearly to our stakeholders. We would like to explore ways to generate graphical and visually engaging reports (charts, dashboards, scorecards, etc.) that can include details such as: User lists Quiz scores Course and program completion status Other performance and engagement metrics Since our organization is already working within the Google ecosystem , we are particularly interested in whether there is a way to: Export or connect Moodle Workplace reporting data to Looker Studio Build custom dashboards with visual reports in Looker Studio Possibly integrate these dashboards back into Moodle Workplace (for example, embedding or linking) If anyone has experience implementing this workflow (Moodle → Looker Studio), or if there are recommended approaches, plugins, or integrations to achieve this, your insights would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance for sharing your experiences and suggestions!

Post title: Reporting and dashboard: Power BI or Superset ?
Post description: Hi all, I know that I posed a very big question but I need some indications from some of you that have already experienced the use of one of the two instruments to make ad hoc reports and dashboard using Moodle API in order to have some better reports than the ones proposed by Moodle inside it. Some of the reports could be: Enrollment Trends : A line chart showing the number of enrollments over time for each course. Grade Distribution : A bar chart displaying the distribution of grades for each student in a selected course. Quiz Scores : A table showing the average quiz scores for each student in a selected course. Discussion Forum Activity : A heatmap visualizing the frequency and timing of discussion posts for each student in a selected course. Completion Course : A table showing the users completed the course and every single course activity. User's Learning Path :  show the courses he/she completed during the years Etc. etc. Any help or link to deepen the issue is very very appreciated.

Post title: Time spent in course with Mobile App
Post description: Hi, Referring to this discussion https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=441131 User's accumulative time spent in course Which uses this code https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports?_gl=1*1550key*_ga*MTAzNzQ0MzMzOS4xNzMyMDIwMzg1*_ga_QWYJYEY9P5*MTc0NDAyMzUxMS4yMS4xLjE3NDQwMjM5ODQuMC4wLjA.#User.27s_accumulative_time_spent_in_course Which is working for me. But is there a better, more efficient way to know how much time a student spent in a course if he is only using the Moodle mobile app? I have found that the logs for web based access vs webservices (app) are very different. You might have only one record for clicking on a page of an assignment if you access with a web browser but several api requests if you are doing it by mobile. Is there a native, more efficient way of knowing how much time a certain student has spent with the mobile app open on a certain Moodle course? Best,

Post title: Multi-course progress report
Post description: We have a vocational program where employees are required to take specific courses in their first two weeks of employment, and then all their courses towards certification within four months. After that, some courses need recertification every year. Others every two years. Is there a plug-in or report that tracks a cohort of learners' progress and completion of multiple courses? Is it possible to send a reminder a month, two weeks, and a week before their time is up? Is there a way of informing a program coordinator (not the instructor) of learners who have not completed the required courses? Thx

Post title: Insight in how Moodle is used (file storage or activities)
Post description: I'd like to get an overview of how Moodle is being used, specifically whether most teachers are primarily using it for "file storage" (Resources) or if they're also incorporating Activities . While I can refer to the Activity overview to see how many different activities are being used, I'd like to gain a deeper understanding. For instance, I'd like to know how these activities are distributed across courses or who created them. Here are a couple of examples to illustrate what I'm looking for: Example 1: We have 2000 quizzes. Are these created by 1000 different teachers, or are a few very active teachers responsible for most of them? Example 2: We have 3000 forums. Are these mostly found in specific courses, such as statistics, or are they spread across various subjects? Is there a way to gather insights into this? It doesn't necessarily have to be based on the examples I've provided; if you can think of another type of overview that might be helpful, I’d appreciate any suggestions.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Triggered event vs. log write timing
Post description: Hello, all. I've written a local plugin to notify certain users when an admin setting has changed. It triggers off of the \core\event\config_log_created event. The problem I'm trying to solve is I want to add the user who made the change in the notification; the config log doesn't store this data. Rather, you have to take the objectid of the event and correlate it to the objectid in the standard log to find the appropriate row, then use the userid field from that row. When I attempt to get_record_ sql ($query) using the id of the event that just occurred, I always get a boolean back (so assuming its not finding the row). However, if I hardcode the query to the id of a previous event, it always returns the userid for me. So, I'm guessing then that the row has not actually been written yet to the standard log when the event handler is executing. I've tried to retrieve the results with a while loop and a time-out condition just in case - after setting the timeout to 2 minutes, it still can't retrieve a row (unless I direct it to search for an objectid from a previous event). Does anyone understand the order of operations here and can explain it to me, how Moodle is triggering events and then logging results, or of another way I might be able to solve this problem? Thanks!!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Clear definition of activity columns statsreads and statswrites
Post description: Hey everyone, At our university, we've been analyzing student activity data across several courses. Our Moodle administrator (we’re currently on Moodle 4.x, I believe version 4.2) provided us with a dataset containing monthly aggregates of student activity. This dataset includes the following columns: id : student identifier courseid : course identifier date : month and year statsreads : integer statswrites : integer Each row represents one student’s activity in a course for a given month, with `statsreads` and `statswrites` representing aggregated actions. However, our administrator couldn’t specify which activities contribute to the `statsreads` and `statswrites` metrics. The site Examulator maps Moodle's relational database (if that’s the correct term) and displays the variables we’re referencing. After some research, we found a few sources that give a vague definition of `statsreads` and `statswrites` : Moodle Docs suggest that in the Stats package, "reads" and "writes" correspond to "view" and "post" actions ( source ). A similar question was asked in the Moodle forum, but no clear answer was provided ( source ). We checked Moodle’s source code on GitHub, but lines 1299–1305 don’t clarify which activities are counted, for example, as "view" ( source ). Penny Leach’s 2005 forum post offers a general definition but lacks specifics ( source ). Are there any official sources that clarify what activities `statsreads` and `statswrites` measure? We don’t need a comprehensive list of every single activity, but a better understanding of what qualifies as, for example, a "view" would be incredibly helpful. Post title: Course Usage Information
Post description: We're interested in getting an idea of how many shells we created each term actually end up getting used by faculty.  Using database queries and the "Moodle Usage Statistics" plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/report_modstats ) I'm able to see, for example, the number of courses by category that have assignment activities .  The idea being courses without Assignments aren't being used.  This is helpful but not an entirely accurate assumption, however, since some faculty might simply use Moodle as a way to share files or links or as a launch point for an external tool. Another idea I had was identifying what a 'default' shell size is to ID courses not being used (aka, not having content uploaded) using the course size plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/report_coursesize ).  This plugin can inflate course sizes and this fails to account for courses that don't have file uploads increasing the disk footprint and instead rely on other activities. Another idea was to find a course last modified date.  Moodle's course table has this, but my understanding is this only records when changes via the course Settings menu have been saved.  This wouldn't track changes to the course like adding a file or modifying an assignment, for example.  There doesn't seem to be a universal last modified value for a course in the database. Has anyone found solutions to gathering usage data either through plugins or database queries that I might be missing?

Post description: We have a course with some SCORM activities . We need to track when users have completed these activities. We use the Activity Completion Report, download it in Excel-compatible mode, and then process the data accordingly. We have some users who are just trainees, and some who are tutors *and* trainees. Until fairly recently, this worked well - the data downloaded for both categories of user. I believe we must have updated our moodle version, and this made it change. (We are currently on 3.10.10) All the categories of user appear in the Activity Completion Report page - the tutors just disappear when we download the report. The tutor users need to be able to view trainee results, and need to be able to add trainees. I guess I could ask them each to have a second trainee-only moodle account, but that feels like a faff. Is there something I can change in the role settings that will fix this?

Forum Post: 
Post title: SQL query to show grade breakdown as percentages
Post description: Evening all. I'm new to Moodle and MySQL and hoping I can get some help with a query I've written.  I'm looking to create a report to show all the assignments per unit, and for each one the percentage of students who received a pass, merit or distinction as well as the percentage of students who have needed to resubmit. I've written the below, and it is showing the assignment names, pass, merit and distinction percentages.  However, it's not showing the correct unit IDs and the resubmission percentage is always showing as 0 which isn't correct as some students have needed to resubmit. Can someone maybe give me some insight into where I'm going wrong? SELECT gi.courseid AS unit_ID, a.name AS assignment_name, COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) AS total_submissions, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 3.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS pass_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 4.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS merit_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 5.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS distinction_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN g.attemptnumber = 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS resubmission_percentage FROM {assign} AS a LEFT JOIN {assign_submission} AS s ON a.id = s.assignment LEFT JOIN {assign_grades} AS g ON s.id = g.assignment JOIN {grade_grades} AS gg ON s.userid = gg.userid INNER JOIN {grade_items} AS gi ON gg.itemid = gi.id GROUP BY gi.courseid, a.name

Post title: Ad-hoc database queries plugin complains at reusing one parameter twice in the query
Post description: I was trying to create a custom report where I parse the file from the URL like this: 
```text
    SELECT CONCAT('https',CHAR(58),'//example.com/report.php',CHAR(63),'contentID=',l.contentID)
    FROM {reporter_links} l
    JOIN {files} f
    ON l.fileid = f.id
    WHERE f.contextid = (SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX((SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX(:url, '/', 5)), '/', -1))
    AND f.itemid=(SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX((SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX(:url, '/', 8)), '/', -1))
    AND f.filename != '.'
```
 This is the error I get: 
```text
Error when executing the query: ERROR: Incorrect number of query parameters. Expected 2, got 1.
```
 I figured out that reusing :url is the culprit. The horrible workaround was to introduce :url2 and paste the link twice in the report GUI. Is there any other way to solve this?

Post title: SQL help - students who enrolled in a course after a specific date
Post description: I'm using an Ad Hoc query to count how many students accessed courses since a certain date. I also want to limit the user count to students who enrolled in the course after a date. I'm having trouble with the last part - where does Moodle store a user's enrollment date for a course? Here's the query so far: 
```text
SELECT c.id, count(u.id)


FROM prefix_user u


JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON (ue.userid = u.id)


JOIN prefix_enrol en ON (en.id = ue.enrolid)


JOIN prefix_course c ON (c.id = en.courseid)


JOIN prefix_context cx ON (cx.instanceid = c.id AND cx.contextlevel = 50)


LEFT JOIN prefix_user_lastaccess ul ON (ul.courseid = en.courseid AND ul.userid = u.id)


WHERE ul.timeaccess > unix_timestamp('2022-09-01')


AND (SELECT count(1) 


FROM prefix_role_assignments ra 


WHERE ra.userid = u.id AND ra.roleid = (5) AND ra.contextid = cx.id)
 > 0


GROUP by c.id


ORDER by count(u.id) DESC
```
 Thank you so much for any help or insight. I'm very new to this.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Marrying Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development
Post description: Problem: Limited Knowledge of Moodle Hamstrings Quality Course Design and Facilitation Quality course design with Moodle is limited by the familiarity of the designer / instructor who  builds / teaches the course. They often do not know what they need to learn next and do not proactively seek out further professional development with Moodle (without incentives). Instead, they typically 'call someone' to find out how to do something in Moodle because they want 'just-in-time-learning'. Solution: Marry Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development Imagine if we were able to combine learning analytics data from Moodle with a smart, Customer Service chatbot? Example: Just take something simple, like the Moodle Assignement type. We can bring a faculty member on a learning path to iterate improvements to their use of this activity. All of their Moodle Assignments reflect their current knowledge level (Lean Prompt + Grade Points + File Submission). We could run analytics on the common settings for all of the Moodle Assignments in their course and detect that they don't have (1) activity completion checked (2) marking guide setup, (3) accepting online submissions, etc. We could expand the list. But here is the important point: We could create a chatbot to popup with suggestions for their 'Next Challenge' on how to 'Moodle Up' their Moodle Assignments, by, say, adding a Marking Guide to make it easier to grade. As you think about this from a pedagogical standpoint, there are iterative sequences we could bring end-users through: Main Course Page = Cluttered, High Use of Descriptions Showing on Main Page > Using Labels to Chunk and Organize > Learning How to Clean up Main Course Page, create Module Overviews, etc. Assignment Prompts =  Long, exhaustive prose and Links > Creating Headers to Organize > HTML Tips to Reduce Cognitive Overload > Use of Accordions to Organize and Show/Hide Content Multimedia = Low detection of Multimedia in Course > How to add External URL Resource / Embed > How to Embed Videos > How to Organize a Multimedia 'Set' File Downloads = Detecting High Number of Documents on Main Course Page > How to use Moodle Files to chunk downloads with files that go together You all probably know quite a few more possibilities . . . !! Just imagine a little chatbot which pops up every once in awhile with a 'Want to Moodle Up?' box and a suggestion to help you 'Moodle Up' your skills in designing with Moodle. This would create *tremendous* leverage for those of us who provide Moodle support to our end-users. We have plenty of tutorials. We can direct them to take webinars. We can point them to Moodle Academy . But this type of 'scaled' professional development—delivered in a 'just-in-time' way (based on analytics of their actual Moodle habits), would be a powerful way to improve Moodle skills at scale . I also think it would keep end-users in that 'flow state', because it is tailored to their current level—giving them just enough new challenge without overwhelming them. I would love to see Moodle HQ think about something like this for future versions of Moodle. It could even be keyed to integrate with resources on Moodle Academy.

Post title: Participation Report with Quiz
Post description: We have been using the Participation report for many years with a variety of activity types. Our teachers use it to bulk contact students who have not completed a particular activity. When using the participation report for a quiz and selecting 'Post' for actions, We assumed that "No" meant students have not completed the quiz and 'Yes' meant that they have completed it. Recently I have noticed our assumptions are incorrect. I ran some tests. "No" means they have not yet viewed the quiz. 'Yes (1)' seems to show that they have viewed a quiz, 'Yes (2)' means they have viewed and attempted it, while 'Yes (3)' shows they have completed the quiz. Higher numbers, like 'Yes (5)' and 'Yes (7)' seem to show that students have completed multiple attempts. It seems like a variety of actions count as posts. Can anyone confirm the same experience?

Post title: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
Post description: Hi everyone, can anyone help me figure out how to pivot data in an Ad Hoc report's SQL query? The examples of pivot statements available online seem straightforward enough, but I'm not able to make it fit my current use case. Here's what I'm attempting to do My query so far is: 
```text
SELECT <fields> 
FROM {user} u INNER JOIN {course_completions} cc ON u.id = cc.userid
INNER JOIN {course} c ON c.id = cc.course 
WHERE c.id in (330, 442)
```
 This gives me a list of every user completion on these specific two courses. Now, I'd like to have the Activity/Module completions (mdl_course_modules and mdl_course_modules_completion) but a JOIN would just create like 10+ rows where I want just one. What I want to do is pivot the data from these two tables, and have it appear as columns, so that each module completion has its own column, and one user's course completion is limited to one row.
Does anyone have any leads on how to do this, or a simple example of pivoting those tables to match my needs? Thanks!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Analytics -- the option to receive emails or not
Post description: Hi all We enabled analytics for this first time (after reading the documentation and watching the explanatory video) and hundreds of our teachers were flooded with collectively >1,000 insight emails. Clearly, this is not ideal. The concept of analytics is a good one. However, there needs to be options and control over how these insights are gathered and distributed. For example, in one circumstance, I may desire site administrators to manually view insights reports periodically. In other circumstances, I may choose that teachers receive email notifications for given models. A blanket "email every teacher in every circumstance", with no ability to set this preference against each model is a poorly conceived approach, and has led to us needing to disable the whole thing. This is a shame as we are missing out on useful information. Please consider introducing emails as an *option* for analytics. Kind Regards Lee Cujes

Forum Post: 
Post title: Log reports frequently "The user with id 'X' changed the password of the user with id 'X'. (Workaround found)
Post description: After bulk importing a user list I found the logfile full of messages: 1850 of this type in under a day. My research led to the following: Accidently two user were created where both Mail addresses contained a german character, the sz (ẞ) symbol. Whereas I am confident that the creation with "umlaut" (e.g. ae, ä) failed at import the sz got through. After disabling a user the reporting stopped immediately. I deleted the users and created them new with their correct address and everything is fine. Maybe theses other entries are related: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=409685 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=410752 Best Bernhard

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Forum Analytics
Post description: Hello! Just brainstorming here: The Moodle Association of Japan moved the reporting about forums forward via the MUA a few release cycles ago. Now, uses have access to a "Summary Report" and users can also "Export" raw forum data for analysis. These are two positives. However, working with these tools and other forum analysis tools, we have discovered things really bog down when the data grows big. Checking relationships between replies (for example) and calculating the depth of replies (for another example) for each user, each group, each grouping , and even analyzing "discussion post by discussion post" gets increasingly complex and taxing on system resources. Would there be any value or benefit in designing (for Moodle) a kind of "Report Caching" system that would periodically update selected tables with summarized data for display? What I mean is that a user chooses the report they want to "cache" and then that report gets run using the specified criteria once every cron cycle (as a scheduled task -- for example -- hourly). Then the data is slowly populated in the background and made available through a single table read and display when the user accesses the report. If there already exists such a system (I'm not talking about configurable reports which require regular users to have a deeper knowledge of SQL ), I'd be interested in learning more about it. If such a system doesn't exist, I suggest (with LA becoming more and more prominent) that Moodle should begin planning one. What do others think?

Post title: Added columns from filter form not in download
Post description: I'm developing a custom report using the table api from here https://docs.moodle.org/dev/lib/tablelib.php I have added a form with a filter that has among other things, checkboxes to add columns of custom user profile field data to the table. All filters are working, and the extra columns are getting added to the table on the page, however, those extra columns are not being downloaded.  I have tried getting the extra column options as an optional parameter on the page and from the form data, but it seems that if it is an added column from those options, then it does not go to the download .  If I hardcode my extra columns rather than get them from the parameters or form data then they do download--so getting them as options from the filter form seems to be the issue. Any ideas as to how I can get the extra columns to go to the download would be greatly appreciated. Thanks

Post title: Unwanted insights emails from hidden courses
Post description: Teachers are complaining about receiving insights emails from hidden courses via the "Students who have not accessed the course recently" analytics model. We have many instances of hidden courses with students enrolments. This is a deliberate choice, not a mistake, as many Teachers make use of meta-link enrolments and teach courses that draw enrolments from these hidden courses. Is there a way we can stop models from generating insights for hidden courses? I see that hidden courses are not included in the "Students at risk of dropping out" model, but it does not appear to be the case for the "not accessed" models. Or have I missed something here?

Post title: Course Logs vs Course Last Activity
Post description: Hi, Forgive me if this has been brought up before, but recently I'm seeing an issue where a user's "Course Last Activity" is not showing an event in the course logs. For example, we have John Smith who's profile in the course shows course last access of 7-1-20, but when checking the course logs there's no event for John Smith beyond 6-23-20. I logged into another course under a test profile and see that even viewing going to the course (without engaging in any content) does still generate a view event in the log.  Furthermore, the is extends beyond the one course as John Smith's "site level" logs show only events up until 6-23-20. His site last access does show a value of 7-1-20. Anyone else experience a similar issue?

Post title: Moodle Tags reporting
Post description: I am sort of stuck
with a project that our university is trying to accomplish. We use
Moodle for all of our assessments in our pharmacy program. Our dean
really wants to generate a report that looks at how well students do on these assessments as they relate
to specific standards in pharmacy. We have initially hypothesized that
his could be accomplished by using the Moodle tag feature. We are
essentially adding tags to all the questions in quiz activity. We are
hoping to be to create a report that looks like this: Course-level Reports A course-level report shows all tags (only tags present in the current course?) from the course with roll-up data for all students. This report should also incorporate a user filter which lets the data be filtered to an individual student. Tag Correct Pts Max Pts Correct % Tag 1 Tag 2 Tag 3 From the course-level tag roll-up, each tag name links to a breakout of the selected tag across all Quiz activities in th at course Tag 1 Course Correct Pts Max Pts Correct % Quiz A Quiz B Quiz C So
far we have achieved a query that will get us a report that shows all
the tags for a particular quiz as a column and the rows are the
students. And that is a good start but where I am getting stuck is we
obviously need the student data to determine the vales but I don't want
to actually have them appear in the table . I am happy to respond with the query that we are already using if that would be helpful! Thank you all, and I would really appreciate any help! I am linking the query that I am currently using . This is the query from the moodle documentation that we are trying to manipulate to meet our needs. https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Questions_which_are_tagged_within_a_course.2Fquiz Any advice would be greatly appreciated. I know that there is a lot in the Moodle Tracker on this but has any progress been made?!?

Forum Post: 
Post title: New plugin Learning Object Relation Discovery (LORD)
Post description: The Learning Object Relation Discovery (LORD) plugin is now available from the plugins directory ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_lord ). This plugin extracts the text content from the learning activities in a course and uses that content to compare the activities against each other, producing a similarity score between each pair of activities. The comparison uses an online sentence similarity calculator ( https://ws-nlp.vipresearch.ca/ ) to determine the similarity values. The similarity calculator uses WordNet, so is currently limited to the English language, but support for Hindi and French are planned for later in 2021. The comparison process runs as a background task and can take some time to complete. Once all the similarity values are known between all the learning objects, the learning object graph (LOG) can be made. A network graph is created where the nodes are the learning objects from the course and the similarity values between objects is used to position the nodes, grouping learning objects with similar content. This plugin can be used by itself to examine the similarity between learning activities and also integrates with the Behaviour Analytics plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_behaviour ). The Behaviour Analytics plugin uses a network graph of learning objects to cluster students according to their behaviour patterns, but the graph nodes are grouped by section and require manual arrangement. The LORD plugin is designed to automatically configure the graph so that it does not have to be manually configured, which should produce better clustering.

Forum Post: 
Post title: New plugin Behaviour Analytics
Post description: Greetings fellow Moodlers, The Behaviour Analytics block plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_behaviour ) has recently been released in the Moodle plugin directory. This plugin provides teachers with a visualization of their students' learning behaviour patterns. Learning modules from a course are used as nodes in a network graph, which can be arbitrarily positioned. Student accesses to the modules create links between the nodes and become the students' behaviour pattern. It is possible to compare the learning patterns of students to see their similarities and differences for various time slices. The plugin also allows students to be clustered according to their behaviour patterns. Each student has a unique pattern that is compressed to a single point, then these student centroid points can be clustered to group students. Clusters of students may have common learning behaviours that can be viewed by hovering over a cluster centroid. It is also possible to annotate the students and clusters during the clustering stage. Currently, the VIP Research Group at Athabasca University ( https://vipresearchgroup.ca/ ) are also developing the LORD (learning Object Relation Discovery) Moodle plugin. The LORD plugin uses WordNet and Natural Language Processing to measure the similarity between two learning objects (activity modules). The similarities are used to automatically position the Learning Object Graph (LOG) nodes, rather than using manual positioning. Presently, only the English language is supported, but there are plans to support French and Hindi next year (2021). The LORD plugin has not yet been released to the Moodle plugin directory, but is available on GitHub ( https://github.com/Behaviour-Analytics/moodle-block_lord ). There is also a new version of Behaviour Analytics plugin available ( https://studyguide.athabascau.ca/networkgraph/download.php ) that is designed to integrate with LORD. Both LORD and the new Behaviour Analytics will get submitted to the Moodle plugin directory later this year.

Post title: Equivalent postgresql code
Post description: Hi all. Sorry if this looks like a newbie problem, because I am a newbie to Moodle and SQL in general. I saw this contributed SQL report written in some SQL DBMS. Now I learned that our Moodle installation uses postgresql and this code doesn't work. 
```text
SELECT 
l.id, 
l.timecreated, 
DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated),'%d-%m-%Y') AS dTime,

@prevtime := (SELECT MAX(timecreated) FROM mdl_logstore_standard_log 
		WHERE userid = %%USERID%% AND id < l.id ORDER BY id ASC LIMIT 1) AS prev_time,

IF (l.timecreated - @prevtime < 7200, @delta := @delta + (l.timecreated-@prevtime),0) AS sumtime,

l.timecreated-@prevtime AS delta,
"User" AS TYPE



FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log AS l, 
(SELECT @delta := 0) AS s_init 


 # CHANGE UserID

WHERE l.userid = %%USERID%% AND l.courseid = %%COURSEID%%

%%FILTER_STARTTIME:l.timecreated:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:l.timecreated:<%%
```
 I would appreciate it if somebody can guide me through re-writing this in postgresql. Thanks in advance!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Analytics in the news
Post description: Here's a thread where any of us can post news items or articles we've seen about analytics and machine learning. My first contribution: Unintended Consequences and Goodhart’s Law: The importance of using the right metrics https://towardsdatascience.com/unintended-consequences-and-goodharts-law-68d60a94705c "Goodhart’s Law is expressed simply as: “When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.” In other words, when we set one specific goal, people will tend to optimize for that objective regardless of the consequences. " Let's think about how this could affect learning analytics. If we don't choose our targets carefully, participants may optimize their participation too narrowly. Here's a example given in the article: "In school, we are given one objective: maximize our grade. This focus on one number can be detrimental to actual learning. High school seemed like one long series of memorizing content for a test, then promptly forgetting it all so I could stuff my brain full of info for the next one, without any consideration of whether I really knew the concepts. This strategy worked quite well given how success was measured in school, but I doubt it is the best approach for a great education." One of the significant-- and often overlooked-- advantages of learning analytics is their potential to detect hidden or "latent" factors in the learning process , not just predict a learning product . What kinds of processes could we detect that would be less prone to "gaming the system" than a final grade prediction?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Users in current course with group and enrolment method
Post description: Hi there, I'm trying to create a report which shows a list of all the people enrolled in a course, along with their groups and enrolment methods. Having multiple lines per user is fine. I just want to create a CSV file that I can then analyse further. Here's what I've got so far. It's returning multiple lines per user, but isn't returning any lines where Group is Null. 
```text
SELECT
Enrolments.CourseName,
Enrolments.EnrolledUserID,
Enrolments.UserEmail,
Enrolments.UserName,
Enrolments.UserCountry,
g.name AS GroupName,
Enrolments.enrolID,
Enrolments.EnrolName,
Enrolments.AutoEnrolName

FROM 
(SELECT
 e.id AS EnrolID,
 e.name AS EnrolName,
 e.customchar2 AS AutoEnrolName,
 c1.id AS CourseID1,
 c1.shortname AS CourseName,
 u1.id AS EnrolledUserID,
 u1.email AS UserEmail,
 u1.username AS UserName,
 u1.country AS UserCountry,
 u1.confirmed AS UserConfirmed,
 u1.deleted AS UserDeleted
 
 FROM prefix_user AS u1
 
 LEFT JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON u1.id = ue.userid
 LEFT JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON e.id = ue.enrolid
 LEFT JOIN prefix_course AS c1 ON e.courseid = c1.id

WHERE c1.id = %%COURSEID%% AND u1.email NOT LIKE "%@xxx.org" AND e.enrol NOT LIKE "manual"

) AS Enrolments

LEFT JOIN prefix_groups_members AS m ON Enrolments.EnrolledUserID = m.userid
JOIN prefix_groups AS g ON m.groupid = g.id
JOIN prefix_course AS c ON g.courseid = Enrolments.CourseID1
```
 What I'd like to end up with is a table like this: User Group Enrolment method John Group 1 Self-enrol 1 John Group 2 Self-enrol 1 Fred Group 1 Auto-enrol Anne Self-enrol 2 Many thanks, Mark

Post title: SQL enhance ad hoc requests with roles
Post description: Hello, we've been using some requests from the ad hoc repositery that is a great help, however i encounter some difficulties with roles assignments. Example with a query that retrieve number of created activities count, here is the initial one that works well. SELECT DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(timecreated), "%d-%m-%Y") AS jour,           SUM(if(m.name = 'assign', 1, 0)) AS devoir, SUM(if(m.name = 'quiz', 1, 0)) AS quiz, SUM(if(m.name = 'forum', 1, 0)) AS forum, SUM(if(m.name = 'chat', 1, 0)) AS chat, SUM(if(m.name = 'resource', 1, 0)) AS fichier, SUM(if(m.name = 'folder', 1, 0)) AS dossier FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log log JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.id = log.objectid JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id = cm.module WHERE  action = 'created' Now we are trying to generate same report for teacher and student roles. Using joins on role_assignments table. Here are the new FROM / JOIN part : FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log log JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.id = log.objectid JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id = cm.module JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = log.userid With this we got too much hits, probably initial count multiplied by how many roles has the user. (Am testing on an invisible course where i created a few different activities). Tried also joining context table with context level set to 70 FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log log JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.id = log.objectid JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id = cm.module JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = log.userid JOIN prefix_context as ctx ON ctx.id = cm.module AND ctx.contextlevel = 70 Also tried to join role assignment and context like this JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = log.userid AND ra.context = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_context as ctx ON ctx.id = cm.module AND ctx.contextlevel = 70 All of the above returns too many count, usually mutliplied by 16 wich looks like maximum assignments role set on the platform. Using ra.roleid = 1 looks ok but not other roles. Anyone to points me in the right direction ?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ad - Hoc Reports Creating User Cumulative Time Spent in Site
Post description: Hallo guys can somebody help me to find out how to create site report of user acces i've found some example but it is spesific on a course here's the code : 
```text
SELECT 
l.id, 
l.timecreated, 
DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated),'%d-%m-%Y') AS dTime,
@prevtime := (SELECT MAX(timecreated) FROM mdl_logstore_standard_log 
		WHERE userid = %%USERID%% AND id < l.id ORDER BY id ASC LIMIT 1) AS prev_time,
IF (l.timecreated - @prevtime < 7200, @delta := @delta + (l.timecreated-@prevtime),0) AS sumtime,
l.timecreated-@prevtime AS delta,
"User" AS TYPE
 
FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log AS l, 
(SELECT @delta := 0) AS s_init 
# CHANGE UserID
WHERE l.userid = %%USERID%% AND l.courseid = %%COURSEID%%
%%FILTER_STARTTIME:l.timecreated:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:l.timecreated:<%%
```

Post title: Ad-hoc customized query - multiple course completions that outputs single row for student
Post description: Hello. I'm hoping that someone has done something like this before and can point me in the right direction. For background, we use a course naming scheme that includes a revision level in the course shortname. For example, the "grape" course is the original course. "grape1" is the first update, "grape2" is the second update, and so on. For our reporting, it doesn't matter which "grape" course the student completed, but they must have completed at least one. But if they've completed more than one, I have to report just the latest completion date of all the "grape" courses they've completed. I thought I could take advantage of the course naming by using "grape%", but I get lost quickly from there. Complicating matters (at least for me) is that we have many "fruit" classes that comprise a track of courses that require completion reporting. For example, a rough pseudocode for this reporting would be: If (student has completed any "apple" course, get its latest completion date) AND (if student has completed any "grape" course, get its latest completion date) AND (if student has completed any " pear " course, get its latest completion date) Then (print MAX(course completion dates from each of the "fruit" courses)) and output "Fruit track completed". Only this one date can be shown on any reports. Any and all suggestions are appreciated, Richard

Forum Post: 
Post title: Risks of predictive analytics?
Post description: Here’s a very interesting post by law professor Frank Pasquale, asking if some kinds of analytics should be done at all, given the potential for harm. https://lpeblog.org/2019/11/25/the-second-wave-of-algorithmic-accountability/ We have the best of intentions for predictive learning analytics, but do these predictions improve learning outcomes, even in the best cases? Do we risk prejudicing teachers about the potential of students, or even activating stereotype threat in students themselves? I hope we can show the value to learners and teachers of learning analytics, and minimize the possible harm. I’ve argued in the past that if we have data and analysis methods that could help learners, we may have an ethical obligation to pursue that potential. But I think we probably shouldn’t assume that any predictive learning analytics system would be “better than nothing.” Thoughts?

Post title: Counting User Logins
Post description: Hiya, I have been using the Statistics report to look at logins to our Moodle. I set the time period and Report Type to Logins. The number of Logins seems very high to me. When I run the following SQL query a colleague wrote I get significantly less logins reported. The query looks at usernames and I can change between Staff and students by changing the u.username (staff have alphabetical, students numerical) SELECT COUNT(u.id), u.username, u.firstname, u.lastname FROM mdl_logstore_standard_log l INNER JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id = l.userid WHERE l.component = 'core' AND l.action = 'loggedin' AND u.username REGEXP '^[a-z]+$' AND FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated, '%Y%m%d') >= 20190801 AND FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated, '%Y%m%d') <= 20190831 GROUP BY u.username Is this query OK? Is there a definative way to get this info? Many thanks, Nige.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Learning Analytics Success Stories - an Invitation
Post description: This message: http://tiny.cc/lastories LMSs are incorporating Learning Analytics tools into their core but the uptake by institutions and lecturers is lagging. If we want to convince educators to use analytics tools, we need good stories - not graphs. At Meital/IUCEL (the Israeli Inter-University Center for E-learning https://meital.iucc.ac.il/en/home-3-2/ ), we’re organising a symposium on “Learning Analytics: From Theory to Practice”. At this event, we intend to share success stories from institutions around the world, and analyse them to identify common challenges and solutions. The event will be webcast live and recorded, and the outputs will be shared under a CC-BY licence. SO if you’re - Involved in teaching Had a problem Adopted a learning analytics solution The problem was addressed (to an extent, at least..) Please share your story with us! To make is easy, we’ve prepared a template for you story, in google doc ( https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dgJS4vYEv0Iq_GzCfiJxfN8SpA8ZaV-_bhU7qv9-kM8/ ) or presentation ( https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1wZnS7Jl8DQwc0Y8Kl7DIxBK5dPELlrhvp2uTpAUvVH4/copy ) form (whichever you prefer). Please share this request widely. If you have any comments, questions or suggestions, please direct them at Nadav Kavalerchik nadavkav@gmail.com & Yishay Mor yish@yishaymor.org .

Forum Post: 
Post title: Restore vs reset and impact on analytics
Post description: My colleague and I have been discussing this topic and it seems time to bring in the big brains. At our university, we run the same courses every semester with new students (like any university). Of course, there might be some small changes each semester but we try to minimize those. We want to use the data we collect to train models, develop interventions, etc. The question is, which is better. Should we reset the course each semester or should be backup and restore it to a new course? More importantly, why exactly should we do that? I understand reset will remove the user data from the course. The logs will remain but all forum posts, grades, etc. will disappear. That said, I believe the grades will still be connected to the user but not to the course. It seems to be that resetting a course is going to lose data and, being the data-hungry person that I am, I would think it would be best to keep all the data and simply run the subsequent courses as new courses. However, my colleague believes that reset would be cleaner (than restore), and would not impact the LA in any way. I can see his point but the technician in me can only see that at least some data is going to be lost in the reset process. Note, the concerns at this point are only about LA. We are not concerned about the student experience of no longer being able to go back and review their old materials online. While that issue might factor into the final decision, here I really want to focus on the LA issues. I would love to know all the details so we can make a decision on this.

Post title: SQL Query
Post description: Hello, I'm working on a report where I am providing all of the grades for a quiz that specific cohorts have taken, however now I've been asked to add the last login for users in this cohort (not necessarily related to this grade event). I need a little assistance with the code to pull last log in information. A lot of the information I've found is for older versions of moodle and don't work in this case. Code in Question is below: SELECT u.firstname AS 'Name', u.lastname AS 'Surname', c.fullname AS 'Course', ch.name AS 'Cohort', CASE WHEN gi.itemtype = 'Course' THEN c.fullname + ' Course Total' ELSE gi.itemname END AS 'Item Name', ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Score, ROUND(gg.rawgrademax,2) AS MAX, ROUND(gg.finalgrade / gg.rawgrademax * 100 ,2) AS Percentage FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid JOIN prefix_cohort_members as cm ON u.id = cm.userid JOIN prefix_cohort as ch ON cm.cohortid = ch.id WHERE ch.name = '****' AND gi.aggregationcoef2 != 0 and c.fullname = '**** Certification v. 1.1'AND gi.itemname = '**** Solutions Certification Exam v. 1.1' ORDER BY `Name` ASC If this is the wrong forum, or perhaps would be a better fit to try and generate in intelliboard, please let me know. Thank you.

Post title: ad-hoc reporting removing underscores from column names
Post description: We have a scheduled report configured for another team which they are using to import and update our HR system. The system requires the field headings to be in uppercase with underscores between the words e.g. START_DATE, END_Date etc. The report works fine but strips the underscores from the column headings. I can force the underscores by inserting &lowbar%%S%% into the query which fixes the display but this then comes through as the html code _ in the csv output. Is there a part of the ad-hoc plugin which removes underscores to aid readability or any way to force the underscores through as they are written? Here's the query: SELECT mu.username AS "PER_REF_NO", DATE_FORMAT( FROM_UNIXTIME( mcmc.timemodified ) , '%Y/%m/%d' ) AS 'START_DATE', DATE_FORMAT( FROM_UNIXTIME( mcmc.timemodified ) , '%Y/%m/%d' ) AS "END_DATE", ms.name AS "TITLE", 'TRUE' as 'COMPLETED_I', 'E-Learning' as 'COURSE_TYPE1' FROM (SELECT * FROM {course_modules_completion} where completionstate = 1) mcmc JOIN {course_modules} mcm ON mcm.id = mcmc.coursemoduleid JOIN { scorm } ms ON mcm.instance = ms.id JOIN {user} mu ON mcmc.userid = mu.id JOIN {course} c ON c.id = mcm.course where mcm.module = 18 #scorm module AND c.id NOT IN (53, 57, 37, 42) AND mu.deleted = 0 AND mu.username NOT LIKE '%admin%' AND c.category != 7 AND DATE_FORMAT( FROM_UNIXTIME( mcmc.timemodified ) , '%Y/%m/%d' ) > DATE_ADD(CURDATE(), INTERVAL -31 DAY) GROUP BY mu.username, ms.name, ms.reference ORDER BY mcmc.timemodified DESC, mu.department, mu.username Thanks, Edd

Forum Post: 
Post title: Activity report grouped by "groups" in course | Query help
Post description: Activity report in Moodle for a course shows Activity, Views and Last access. We require this data to be broken down into groups present in the course. How many views were made to an activity by the unique users present in a particular group. For this we have managed to write the below query. The problem here is that the users which are not present in any course groups are not accounted for! why is that? there is a Left join which should instruct SQL to also pick records which are not present in any groups. Please help, SELECT ug.groupid, grps.name, slog.contextinstanceid as cmid, COUNT('x') AS numviews,
COUNT(DISTINCT slog.userid) AS distinctusers, MAX(slog.timecreated) AS lasttime FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log AS slog LEFT JOIN prefix_groups_members AS ug ON ug.userid = slog.userid INNER JOIN prefix_groups AS grps ON grps.id=ug.groupid WHERE grps.courseid = 2156
AND slog.courseid = 2156
AND slog.anonymous = 0
AND slog.crud = 'r'
AND slog.contextlevel = 70 GROUP BY slog.contextinstanceid, ug.groupid

Post title: Ad Hoc activity completion report (on not completed activities)
Post description: Hi, I'm new to SQL so am struggling with producing a custom report. There doesn't appear to be a database entry for each user created for an activity unless they interact with the activity.
```text
SELECT


u.firstname AS 'Firstname',


u.lastname AS 'Lastname',


u.email AS 'Email',


CONCAT(u.firstname, ' ', u.lastname) AS `Name`,


c.shortname AS 'Course',


m.name AS Activitytype, 


CASE 


    WHEN cm.module = 1 THEN (SELECT a1.name FROM prefix_assign a1            WHERE a1.id = cm.instance)


    WHEN cm.module = 2 THEN (SELECT a2.name FROM prefix_assignment a2    WHERE a2.id = cm.instance)


    WHEN cm.module = 3 THEN (SELECT a3.name FROM prefix_book a3               WHERE a3.id = cm.instance)


    WHEN cm.module = 4 THEN (SELECT a4.name FROM prefix_chat a4                WHERE a4.id = cm.instance)
```

Post title: SQL Query help please - to pull custom user profile field and course data
Post description: Hi, I'm using OpenLMS (Moodlerooms) 3.5 and trying to build a SQL query to generate an admin report with: Student first name | Last name | Org ID number (custom profile) | Course name | Completion date. I do not know SQL and for some reason, none of the SQL syntax from the adhoc contributed reports website works. Obviously I'm doing something wrong or OpenLMS/Moodlerooms requires a slightly different format of those queries? Keep getting the error "The SQL entered is not supported by this report or is incorrect. Error reading from database ". After many tries, the following format of code works, so can someone please guide on how to change this code to pull the above 5 pieces of data? Thanks very much! PS SELECT d.userid AS userid, MAX(CASE WHEN f.shortname = 'Field1 Short Name' THEN d.data ELSE '' END) AS FieldName1, MAX(CASE WHEN f.shortname = 'Field2 Short Name' THEN d.data ELSE '' END) AS FieldName2 FROM mdl_user_info_data d JOIN mdl_user_info_field f ON d.fieldid = f.id GROUP BY d.userid

Forum Post: 
Post title: Please read: How to develop custom reports
Post description: Moodle provides two general types of reports in Core: Course reports Site-wide reports Other general documentation about reports is here . Moodle does not, at this time, include a general-purpose reporting tool in Core. If you need reports other than those provided in Moodle Core, you have several options: Use Moodle Workplace Install a plugin that includes a specific report Write a new report in PHP using the reports API Use one of several flexible reporting plugins, including: Ad-Hoc Database Queries Configurable Reports Third party solutions like Intelliboard If you have questions about what plugins are available or how to develop reports using one of these tools, please post here and the community may be able to help. If you are interested in supporting inclusion of a reporting tool within Moodle Core, please see MDL-62080 .

Forum Post: 
Post title: SQl query help please
Post description: Hi I was wondering if someone can check my SQL query below and let me know if i have done it right? Basically I need the results of people who have passed our courses however some courses have an option where learners can do the pre-quiz and if they pass this they don't need to take the full course. So for example i need to see what course activity they have taken and the grade for this. thank you SELECT u.username AS Username,u.firstname AS 'First' , u.lastname AS 'Last', u.email AS 'User Email', dept.data Department, c.fullname AS 'Course', gi.itemname AS 'Activity', ROUND(gg.finalgrade,0) as Grade, DATE_FORMAT( FROM_UNIXTIME( gg.timemodified ) , '%d/%m/%Y' ) AS date FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_context AS ctx ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN prefix_role AS r ON r.id = ra.roleid AND r.shortname = 'student' JOIN prefix_user AS u ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN prefix_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.userid = u.id JOIN prefix_grade_items AS gi ON gi.id = gg.itemid JOIN prefix_course_categories AS cc ON cc.id = c.category LEFT JOIN prefix_user_info_data dept on dept.userid = u.id and dept.fieldid = 3 LEFT JOIN prefix_user_info_data spec on spec.userid = u.id and spec.fieldid = 1 WHERE  gi.courseid = c.id AND gi.itemtype = 'mod' AND u.email NOT LIKE '%@bwnft.nhs.uk%' AND gg.finalgrade>= '65' %%FILTER_STARTTIME:gg.timemodified:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:gg.timemodified:<%% GROUP BY u.id, c.id, gg.id, gi.id,ctx.id, cc.id ORDER BY u.lastname

Post description: I'm thinking about using Moodle for corporate learning portals. Most traditional concepts use an LMS for complians and Health&Safety courses. But Moodle specially is ideal to open the learning world to completely different concepts like: learning nuggets open courses project groups user generated content In a more lively LMS environement one element will be to give the user motivation, suggestions, recommendation about other learning issues/topice/courses that may be interesting for him. The LA concept is primarily oriented in analysing behaviour in one course and give the teacher information to support. The same model should work  when we use when we analyse existing courses/ course activities a user completed and to give him  suggestions to other courses/content that has additonal topics. This could be based on tags or other types of metadata . In combination with search engine features it should be possible to create automatical tags. What do you think about this?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Predicting -- and changing -- the future of education with Moodle's Learning Analytics Online Workshop Series
Post description: At Moodle we use sophisticated software algorithms to help predict outcomes and reveal hidden aspects of a learner’s process. This information can then be used by Moodle users to improve how they teach and learn. Our Learning Analytics ( available with Moodle 3.4 and above ) uses historical data and current behavior to predict student dropout risk, based on the research-supported Community of Inquiry theoretical framework-- and to change these outcomes for the better. Also, its API allows anyone to build additional models to suit their unique needs. Learning analytics is an effective tool to empower educators, but it can be challenging to understand and implement, which is why we have introduced a new Workshop Series in Moodle’s Learning Analytics Working Group (LAWG). This free workshop series is designed to teach you how to extend the analytics capabilities of Moodle users in two ways: For educators and researchers, learn how to design new models for specific educational purposes, and specify them so they can be developed to match those purposes. Developers, learn how to implement new models by extending the API. In addition to being completely free, LAWG and the Workshop Series are always open, ensuring that anyone can join at their own pace. As well as improving their skills, successful LAWG Workshop participants will have the opportunity to evaluate assignments and award badges using our peer-review process. This online workshop series builds on the very successful Moot workshops we’ve offered in the past. It opens up opportunities for educators, researchers, and developers to participate, no matter where they are. We’re very excited to be able to open these resources up to the whole Moodle Learning Analytics community. What are you waiting for? Join our free working group to improve your Learning Analytics skills. Thanks for your participation! Elizabeth Dalton Research Analyst, Moodle HQ

Post title: log all activities of a user during the course.
Post description: Hi, I want to know a query where I can see a user and name of all activities with their timestamps performed during the course. I have a query where It counts the activities but  instead I want to know the exact activity name with their time stamps for each student enrolled in the course. This is query that I am using for count of activities. select l.component AS activity , COUNT(DISTINCT case when l.timecreated-c.startdate < 0 then l.id else NULL end) AS BeforeTerm , COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 0 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week1, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 1 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week2, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 2 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week3, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 3 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week4, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 4 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week5, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 5 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week6, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 6 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week7, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 7 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week8, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 8 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week9, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 9 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week10, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 10 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week11, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) = 11 then l.id else NULL end) AS Week12, COUNT(DISTINCT case when FLOOR((l.timecreated - c.startdate)/(60*60*24*7)) >= 12 then l.id else NULL end) AS AfterTerm, COUNT(l.id) AS Total FROM mdl_user AS u JOIN mdl_role_assignments AS ra ON u.id = ra.userid JOIN mdl_context AS ctx ON ra.contextid = ctx.id JOIN mdl_course AS c ON c.id = ctx.instanceid JOIN mdl_course_categories AS cc ON c.category = cc.id LEFT JOIN mdl_logstore_standard_log AS l ON l.userid = u.id AND l.courseid = c.id  AND l.crud IN ('c','u') GROUP BY l.component ORDER BY l.component second question: I have two tables in my database one is mdl_log and second is mdl_standard_log. I also want to know the difference between both.

Post description: Hi everyone, I'm working on a plugin that *reads* information from database and create some graphic visualisation. My graphs are outputted by Moodle core function Chart.js. Forum Post: 
Post title: Analytics Admins perspective
Post description: Here some more questions now from Admins perspective: Is it possible to define courses that are used for a model for training purpose? Is it possible to exclude/include categories of courses for training? What happens if a course that was used for training purpose is reset or deleted with the data? What are the minimal number of courses /users required for training until we will have relevant data for predictions? Are the data from courses where predictions are given added to the basis of data for future predictions? How can we delete data if an institution changes significant the teaching model/didactical scenario and need a new training process? It should be possible to delete or ignore old data and not to mix them with data in a new concept. Can we get different models and predictions for different groups of courses? The results and predictions may be very different for classes 1-4 or 10-12 in the same institution, Same could happen with different target groups or programs (i.e. in German vocational schools). Is there a list of site and course settings that are required? A course scenario may have a weekly quiz. The students results and behaviour in these quizzes inrelation to the progression of complexity between the quizzes is an interesting model for prediction. Some aspects: number of attempts up to passing grade, attempts after passing grade is reached,.. Is it possible to move a model with training data from one system to an other? Scenario: a schoolbook publisher sells a course. Over time ten thousands of students runs through this course. With the next edition of the course the publisher wants to add the option that a school gets predictions from the first use of the course based on the experience of students from other schools. Is it possible to export/import a model between Moodle systems? What is the sense of a prediction befor the course starts? Which user data are used for such a  prediction? (mentioned in https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Analytics_API#How_many_predictions_for_each_sample.3F ) How can we communicate realistic expectations about the information/predictions that models can create. Analytics is not the fortune tellers  glas ball. But some people will think it will do it and have expectations that are not realistic.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Course Creation Dates
Post description: I just tried to whip up a little SQL report that would give me details of all new courses (from mdl_course) created in the last week.  I was hoping to run this weekly. 
```text
SELECT *
FROM prefix_course
WHERE from_unixtime(timecreated)>CURDATE() - interval 7 DAY
```
 However, it hit a snag when I discovered that the neither the "timecreated" nor the "timemodified" fields contain the time the actual course record was created. Here's the issue: When we create a new course, we create it by restoring a backup file of a standard template that was created some time ago. When I restore to a new course, using that template, the "timecreated" just copies the value from the original template, rather than using the time that that particular course record was created. Does anyone know where I can find the timestamp for the actual creation of a new course?

Post title: Yearly usage
Post description: Hi, We are using the ad-hoc reports. We need to know the number of users how uses Moodle on a yearly bases. We found one query that gives monthly but we need yearly one. This the one available: Monthly Usage by Role This report shows a distinct count of users by their role, accessing your site. Each instance of user and role is counted once per month, no matter how many courses they access. We use this to show the total number of students and teachers accessing our site. 
```text
SELECT
 

MONTH
(
from_unixtime
(
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`timeend`
)
)
 
AS
 calendar_month
,


YEAR
(
from_unixtime
(
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`timeend`
)
)
 
AS
 calendar_year
,

prefix_role
.
name 
AS
 user_role
,


COUNT
(
DISTINCT
 prefix_stats_user_monthly
.
userid
)
 
AS
 total_users

FROM

prefix_stats_user_monthly

INNER
 
JOIN
 prefix_role_assignments 
ON
 prefix_stats_user_monthly
.
userid 
=
 prefix_role_assignments
.
userid

INNER
 
JOIN
 prefix_context 
ON
 prefix_role_assignments
.
contextid 
=
 prefix_context
.
id

INNER
 
JOIN
 prefix_role 
ON
 prefix_role_assignments
.
roleid 
=
 prefix_role
.
id

WHERE
 prefix_context
.
contextlevel 
=
 
50


AND
 
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`stattype`
 
=
 
'activity'


AND
 prefix_stats_user_monthly
.
courseid 
<>
1


GROUP
 
BY
 
MONTH
(
from_unixtime
(
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`timeend`
)
)
,


YEAR
(
from_unixtime
(
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`timeend`
)
)
,

prefix_stats_user_monthly
.
stattype
,

prefix_role
.
name

ORDER
 
BY
 

YEAR
(
from_unixtime
(
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`timeend`
)
)
,
 
MONTH
(
from_unixtime
(
`prefix_stats_user_monthly`
.
`timeend`
)
)
,

prefix_role
.
name
```
 We need the same result but on a yearly bases to know exactly how many users where using the site every year. Thank you indeed. Salim

Post title: SQL queries for Discussion Forum analysis
Post description: Not sure which Moodle Forum to post this in, but so far I have got no reply in the General Development forum so I will try here. I need to develop some analytics on discussion forum activity. Specifically, I would like to query the Moodle (3.1 or 3.2) database to get the following data for activity in a specified discussion forum of a specified course. (The data will later be analyzed against in-person interviews with the users, to study effectiveness of the Forum activities .) 1. For every pair of users in the course, say "user-A" and "user-B", how many times did user-A
reply to a post by user-B (no matter if it was to a new base note or to a
reply of user-B), and vice versa. (Researching network connectedness and "symmetry" between users
in Forums. The Forum Graph plugin depicts this but doesn't return downloadable data as far as I know. What SQL would do so?) 2. For every pair of users in the course, user-A and user-B, what was the average "rating" user-A and user-B
gave each other's posts (no matter if it was to a new base note or to a
reply of user-A). (Researching connectedness and "symmetry" between users
in Forums, correlated with perceived Quality of Forum activity. Don't know of anything that returns this data.) 3. How many times did each user post (whether a new topic or a reply) to anyone else in the course. (Level of activity. Available in core Moodle Reporting but I would like to know what SQL to use to get results for specific users, course, forum.) 4. What was the average rating overall that each user received for postings (for new topic and replies) by all other users in the course, in the aggregate. (Quality of activity as measured by all peers. Don't know of anything that returns this data.) Can anyone point me to the right queries that would do the above, or which I could use as a starting point for development? Thanks, Alan

Forum Post: 
Post title: Which SQL Table and column captures course activity completion timestamps?
Post description: Hello, I've been working on custom SQL reports on primarily SCORM activities within a given course. The scorm table from the sql database shows start time but not completion timestamp. In layman's terms I can know when a learner starts a SCORM activity but not when it is completed. It does tell me how much time is spent - which is a good statistic - but I want to close it off with the completion date and time. On the other hand, Moodle course-level reports - namely Activity Completion, seem to populate this information with ease. They show the timestamp of completion for every applicable activity in the course (be it SCORM or non-scorm). However, I cannot identify which sql table and/or columns it retrieves this data from. Does anyone know where in the database specifically this is stored?

Post title: SQL Query for Custom Profile Fields & Enrolled Course Completion
Post description: I need to put together a site level (cot course level) custom report that appears as follows: Name, Profile_Field_1, Profile_Field_2, Profile_Field_3, Profile_Field_4, Profile_Field_5, Complete, Jane Smith, a, b, c, d, e, Yes, Where all Profile_Fields are custom user profile fields & 'Complete' is whether a student has completed all courses they're enrolled in. I'm finding the structure of Moodle's tables very confusing where it comes to profile fields - I've never worked with tables that are nested the way these are before. I'm not sure where to start on the course completion column. My failing query so far: SELECT CONCAT (u.firstname, u.lastname) Name, d1.data Profile_Field_1, d2.data Profile_Field_2, d3.data Profile_Field_3, d4.data Profile_Field_4, d5.data Profile_Field_5, IF (ROUND(g.finalgrade / g.rawgrademax * 100, 2) > 79, 'Yes', 'No') Complete FROM mdl_user u LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_data d1 ON d1.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_field f1 ON f1.id = d1.fieldid AND f1.shortname = " Profile_Field_1 " LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_data d2 ON d2.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_field f2 ON d2.fieldid = f2.id AND f2.shortname = " Profile_Field_2 " LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_data d3 ON d3.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_field f3 ON d3.fieldid = f3.id AND f3.shortname = " Profile_Field_3 " LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_data d4 ON d4.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_field f4 ON d4.fieldid = f4.id AND f4.shortname = " Profile_Field_4 " LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_data d5 ON d5.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_field f5 ON d5.fieldid = f5.id AND f5.shortname = " Profile_Field_5 " LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_data d6 ON d6.userid = u.id LEFT JOIN mdl_user_info_field f6 ON d6.fieldid = f6.id AND f6.shortname = " Profile_Field_6 " JOIN mdl_grade_grades g ON g.userid = u.id GROUP BY u.id ORDER BY `Name` ASC Any help would be very much appreciated. Thanks.

Post title: Big Problem with Activity Report Data
Post description: So a colleague and I just encountered with a 2.8.7 instance and a 2.7.3 instance that the Activity report in Administration block > Course administration sums the views of all roles in the course including the teacher role! Try it yourself and run an Activity report then click a resource or activity. Run the report again and it will have incremented by one. This is true in the latest release 3.0 and the 3.1 prototypes. I can't expect any teacher would care how many times they click on their own resources. What they really want (and expect) to see from this report is how their class of students are engaging in the course content.  So, in this current state, this report is not providing any good data for the teacher role it is created for. If teachers really want to see a report on their own activity, they can do that under My profile settings > Activity reports > Outline report. If anyone has input on this and agrees with me, I am happy to submit a tracker item to request this gets adjusted so only student role is shown by default and there is a pulldown menu to filter by other roles.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SQL query for quiz answers
Post description: Hi, I created a query to get the answers for each question from the highest scored attempt for each student: 
```text
select u.username, question.name, case when qas.state = "gradedright" or qas.fraction = qatt.maxmark then 1 else 0 end correct
	FROM mdl_quiz AS q
		JOIN mdl_course_modules AS cm ON cm.instance = q.id
		JOIN mdl_quiz_attempts qa ON q.id = qa.quiz
			and qa.id = (
				select id
				from mdl_quiz_attempts
				where quiz = q.id
					and userid = u.id
				ORDER BY sumgrades DESC
				LIMIT 1
			)
		JOIN mdl_user AS u ON u.id = qa.userid
		JOIN mdl_question_usages AS qu ON qu.id = qa.uniqueid
		JOIN mdl_question_attempts AS qatt ON qatt.questionusageid = qu.id
		JOIN mdl_question AS question ON question.id = qatt.questionid
		JOIN mdl_question_attempt_steps AS qas ON qas.questionattemptid = qatt.id
			and qas.id = (
			    SELECT sortqas.id
			    FROM mdl_question_attempt_steps sortqas
			    WHERE sortqas.questionattemptid = qatt.id
				ORDER BY sortqas.timecreated DESC
				LIMIT 1
		    )
	    JOIN mdl_course crs on crs.id = cm.course
	WHERE cm.id = ?
```
 However, it seems some of the correct answers are registered with mdl_question_attempt_steps.state = "completed" instead of "gradedright" , so I considered mdl_question_attempt_steps.fraction = mdl_question_attempts.fraction as correct answers as well. Can someone please tell me if this is a consistent consideration or if it has any issues like precision differences or whatever? Also, is there a better way to determine correct answers? Thanks!

Post title: Activity reports need a common field
Post description: I am trying to link data from two separate activities : a Feedback activity and a Quiz activity. I would be fine exporting the reports for each as long as I had a common field that I could use as a key. What I need and what I get from the Feedback activity: I want a report of student responses to include a field to use as a key. When I export the responses for the Feedback activity, I get a report that includes USERNAME and FULL NAME fields. What I need and what I get from the Quiz activity: I want a report of student responses to include a field to use as a key. When I export the responses for the Quiz activity, I get a report that includes FIRST NAME , LAST NAME , and EMAIL . Why don't the reports both include common identifying fields? Username or Email fields would be fine. UserID would be great. But, as it stands, I wouldn't be able to tell the difference between two students with the same name because there is no unique identifier that is common between the reports. I would have to pull up a separate report of Enrolled Users just so that I can cross-reference by USERNAME and EMAIL so I could tell who is who. I would like two things that would help me out tremendously: 1. If anyone knows how to add a common field to either report, please let me know. 2. If the built-in queries and reports could be adjusted to include a common identifying field, I could do much more with the reports.

Post title: Custom report with Course and Quiz results - I'm missing something
Post description: Using Moodle 2.9 I would like to have a report that shows the Course Name with the Quiz Name and Quiz Results for the past 24 hours (sorted by Course Name). Here's what the current report looks like: itemname grademax finalgrade firstname lastname username idnumber days Day 2 (Wave 3) 100.00000 91 Thomas Dixxn tdixxn 82xx1 2015-09-10 17:00:14 Types of Waste 100.00000 77 Thomas Dixxn tdixxn 82xx1 2015-09-10 17:00:14 Day 3 (Wave 3) 100.00000 100 Thomas Dixxn tdixxn 82xx1 2015-09-10 17:00:14 Friday Review 4.10.15 100.00000 99 Thomas Dixxn tdixxn 82xx1 2015-09-10 17:00:14 Day 4 (Wave 3) 100.00000 90 Thomas Dixxn tdixxn 82xx1 2015-09-10 17:00:14 Day 8 (Wave 3) 100.00000 89 Thomas Dixxn tdixxn 82xx1 2015-09-10 17:00:14 Here's the current code: 
```text
SELECT 


     prefix_grade_items.itemname,


     prefix_grade_items.grademax,


     ROUND(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade, 0) AS finalgrade,


     prefix_user.firstname,


     prefix_user.lastname,


     prefix_user.username,


    prefix_user.idnumber,


    FROM_UNIXTIME(`lastlogin`) AS days
```

Post description: Hi, I am having trouble generating a report with the following information: - All users (first name, last name, email) - Course name - Last access date (or "Never Access" if the user has never logged in) - Final grade - some custom fields I created for users I am using the ad-hoc query plugin but I am not able to get the report I want. I am getting many duplicates on the query results. I am getting four identical rows for each user (I know it has something to do with the custom fields, since there are 4 of those, but have not been able to figure out how to solve it) Here is a copy of the query I am running (it does not have the grades information, since I have not been able to figure that out yet) SELECT u.firstname as nombre, u.lastname as apellido, u.email as email, c.shortname as curso, IF(ue.status = 0, 'Active', 'Suspended') as estado, e.enrol, FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timecreated, '%m/%d/%Y %h:%i:%s %p') as fecha_registro, IF(ue.timestart = 0, 'No End Date',FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timestart, '%m/%d/%Y %h:%i:%s %p')) as inicio_registro, IF(ue.timeend = 0, 'No End Date',FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timeend, '%m/%d/%Y %h:%i:%s %p')) as fin_registro, COALESCE(( SELECT FROM_UNIXTIME(la.timeaccess,'%m/%d/%Y %h:%i:%s %p') FROM prefix_user_lastaccess as la WHERE u.id = la.userid AND c.id = la.courseid ), 'Nunca') as Ultimo_Acceso, ( SELECT info.fieldid FROM prefix_user_info_data as info WHERE info.userid = u.id AND info.fieldid = '4' ) as Regional, ( SELECT info.fieldid FROM prefix_user_info_data as info WHERE info.userid = u.id AND info.fieldid = '5' ) as Ciudad, ( SELECT info.fieldid FROM prefix_user_info_data as info WHERE info.userid = u.id AND info.fieldid = '6' ) as Provincia, ( SELECT info.fieldid FROM prefix_user_info_data as info WHERE info.userid = u.id AND info.fieldid = '7' ) as Franquicia FROM prefix_user_enrolments as ue, prefix_enrol as e, prefix_course as c, prefix_user as u, prefix_user_info_data as tabla_regional WHERE ue.userid = u.id AND ue.enrolid = e.id AND e.courseid = c.id AND tabla_regional.userid = u.id ORDER BY u.lastname, u.firstname, c.startdate DESC, c.shortname
