Post title: No record of grade/activity, but there's an entry in the gradebook?
Post description: I created a report that gets the times of the first access logged for a user in a course and the last grade recorded in that course, and uses the difference to estimate the time spent in the course. However, someone noted that one user isn't showing up in the report, and the more I investigate why, the more confused I get. The user in question has ID 98, and the course has ID 79. If I go to a gradebook page, like .../grade/report/user/index.php?userid=98&id=79 on my site, the user definitely has a grade recorded for the course (a single activity course based on a SCORM object, in case that matters). However, I can't find any evidence of this anywhere in the database . There are no entries in the grade_grades table for that user and course (though there are entries for the user in other courses, and for the course with other users), nor can I even find anything in the logs table for that user in that course, even though I should have records going back for years. The one thing I can think of is that this user has a custom system role assigned, which is derived from the Manager role, and something in the back of my brain is telling me there's some setting somewhere that causes such users' activities to not be logged? Or maybe I'm completely mis-remembering that. If there is such a setting, I can't find it, and anyway it doesn't explain why he has logs for other courses (unless maybe they're from before he was assigned the role?) Anyway, I'm grasping at straws here. It seems that if user X has a grade in course Y's gradebook, then it there *should* be an entry for that user/course combo in the grade_grades table... right? Before I start digging into the source code, I figured I'd ask here in case I'm just missing something obvious. Thanks to anyone who can help! Here are examples of some of the queries I've tried. Both of these return no results as-written, but if you remove the user or course restrictions, then they do. 
```text
select itemname, g.rawgrade from mdl_grade_items i join mdl_grade_grades g on i.id = g.itemid and g.userid=98 and courseid=79;
```
 
```text
select u.username, c.fullname, action, min(time) first from mdl_log l join mdl_user u on l.userid = u.id and u.id = 98 and course=79 join mdl_course c on l.course = c.id group by username,fullname,action
```

Forum Post: 
Post title: Reporting using SQL directly on mdl_logstore_standard_log
Post description: I am using the mdl_Logstore_standard_log to create graphs and detailed analysis of pages visited on our system. However I am seeing multiple log entries for students when visiting pages that are within seconds of each other, which effectively reports that more visits than is actually happening. i.e. A student lands on our home page, and the log shows that there are three records for the same student going to that page and they are all timed within around 10 seconds, when in fact they have only looked at that page once. Could anyone explain why this could be please, is this logging when different blocks have been loaded on the page perhaps I have also included my SQL code to assist Any assistance would be greatly appreciated. select  mdl_logstore_standard_log. id, mdl_logstore_standard_log. ip, mdl_logstore_standard_log. courseid, mdl_logstore_standard_log.target, mdl_logstore_standard_log. action, moodle.mdl_user.username, moodle.mdl_course.fullname, moodle.mdl_course_categories.name as Category, concat (moodle.mdl_user.firstname, ' ', moodle.mdl_user.lastname) as Who, moodle.mdl_user.email, from_unixtime(mdl_logstore_standard_log.timecreated) as TheTime From moodle.mdl_logstore_standard_log WHERE (mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='630' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='631' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='610' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='635' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='607' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='581' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='640' or mdl_logstore_standard_log.courseid ='625') and (mdl_logstore_standard_log.timecreated > unix_timestamp('2014-10-01 00:00:00') AND mdl_logstore_standard_log.timecreated < unix_timestamp('2014-10-31 00:00:00')) and action = 'viewed' and target = 'course' ;

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ad hoc queries Report code modifcation - help?
Post description: Hi everyone, We have been using the following SQL to pull a report showing all course completions for all users on our site so we can export this information to our student information system (SAP). The report, as you can imagine, is getting longer and longer as more completions are added. 
```text
SELECT u.idnumber, u.firstname, u.lastname, c.fullname as course, FROM_UNIXTIME(com.timecompleted-(0*60*60), '%M %d, %Y') as coursecompleted, FROM_UNIXTIME(max(st.timemodified)-(0*60*60), '%M %d, %Y') as scormcompleted 


FROM prefix_scorm_scoes_track st


JOIN prefix_scorm s ON s.id = st.scormid


JOIN prefix_course c ON c.id = s.course


JOIN prefix_user u ON u.id = st.userid


JOIN prefix_course_completions com ON com.course = c.id AND com.userid = u.id


WHERE st.element = 'cmi.core.lesson_status' AND (st.value = 'completed' OR st.value = 'passed') AND com.timecompleted IS NOT NULL


GROUP BY u.idnumber, u.firstname, u.lastname, scormid, c.fullname, com.timecompleted
```
 I'd like to offer my coordinators two report options from here on out: 1) The report with the information from the original query but limited to just the completions for the previous 30 days. We pull the report weekly so having a rolling 30 days would give us enough overlap to catch errors. 2) The full report from the original query but that doesn't display the table in HTML in Moodle; it would just give us the option to download the csv. I don't know SQL at all and someone else wrote the code for us originally. Can anyone help me make the modifications? Thank you so much in advance! Leah Hemeon

Forum Post: 
Post title: Issues with Stats gathering and Cron
Post description: Over the years I have had intermittent issues with running the Moodle cron and populating the statistical tables via it. Across the Moodle forums there are a number of discussions on the subject and suggested fixes. The most recent problems have been with Moodle 2.6 and hopefully what I found can be of use. a) Ignore all advice about fiddling with timestamps, time functions etc in the admin/cron.php file, it's fine. b) In lib/cronlib.php there is a section where it runs stats gathering for  'all other' plugins (about line 440). Unfortunately there are some filter and repository plugins that appear not to have been written correctly and so when the cron reaches this stage it throws an error and dies.  As yet I have not had the time to determine which specific filter(s) or repository is causing the problem, so as a stop gap  I comment out those functions and stop them running.  I think there needs to be some stricter testing imposed on non-standard filters / repositories to prevent this at source. c) When processing the logs and getting them in the desired format for insertion into the stats tables, the data is understandably stored in temp tables  first.  Unfortunately it appears that the field sizes of the temp tables do not match those of the log table and so data can not be inserted and the process stops. This has been a particular issue with the action field for example with the value "moodle_user_get_course_participants_by_id".  This may have been fixed in 2.7 but if not it's worth having a look at. Using Moodle is a huge part of our curriculum delivery and the more stats the merrier as far as my senior managers are concerned, so I'm looking forward to looking at the additions for 2.7

Post title: Troubleshoot an ad-hoc database query
Post description: Hi all, thanks for reading this thread. I'm working on the following database query (using Ad-hoc database query plugin), and this is what I have now: ------------- SELECT u.id AS 'user ID', concat(u.firstname, ' ',u.lastname) AS name, c.id AS 'Course_ID', c.fullname AS 'Course', g.id as 'Group ID', g.name as 'Group_Name', u.email AS 'Email address', da.fieldid AS 'Field ID', da.data AS 'Job_title/Employer/Primary', CASE WHEN gi.itemtype = 'Course' THEN c.fullname + ' Course Total' ELSE gi.itemname END AS 'Item Name', ROUND(gg.finalgrade,2) AS Score,ROUND(gg.rawgrademax,2) AS MAX, ROUND(gg.finalgrade / gg.rawgrademax * 100 ,2) AS Percentage, IF (ROUND(gg.finalgrade / gg.rawgrademax * 100 ,2) > 79,'Yes' , 'No') AS Pass FROM prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_groups AS g ON g.courseid = c.id JOIN prefix_groups_members AS m ON g.id = m.groupid JOIN prefix_user AS u ON m.userid = u.id --------------- As you can see the current query will generate a list of students (and which group they belong to) in a specific course (course id 101), and list out who passed (or not pass) the final exam. However, it seems that the query will NOT include students who didn't try the final exam (with no assessment score). Is there a way to fix this issue so that it would also display those students who did not take the final exam (but are enrolled in the same course)? Thanks for your help! Judy

Is querying the mdl_log table suitable or going to balloon the time it takes to process (the reason I've chosen it is that it already provides a great level of detail) The output when the user clicks a 'Submit' button once selecting from the dropdown boxes, will be a table of data resulting from the query that matches their input. Sorry it's quite a longwinded question, I've just been shifting through masses of code from core plugins to third-party ones and they have many different ideas and ways of implementation, so I thought I'd try and pick the minds of people here who could give me a push in the right direction. Post title: SQL Help
Post description: With the help of my IT person, I was able to write this code to get information on who has received their certificate. The issue I am having however is the course names in the report appear to be wrong and one of my criticle courses is missing from the report. Does anyone know how to modify this so that I get all of my courses, the students name, address, company, when they recieved their certificate and the verification code for the cert? SELECT concat(mdl_user.firstname, ' ', mdl_user.lastname) AS Name, (select data from mdl_user_info_data a where fieldid = 3 and userid = mdl_user_info_data.userid ) as company, mdl_course.shortname AS Coursename, mdl_certificate.name AS Certificate, mdl_certificate_issues.code AS VerificationCode, DATE_FORMAT( FROM_UNIXTIME(mdl_certificate_issues.timecreated), '%m/%d/%y' ) AS DATE, mdl_grade_grades.finalgrade, (select data from mdl_user_info_data a where fieldid = 5 and userid = mdl_user_info_data.userid ) as address, mdl_user.city, (select data from mdl_user_info_data a where fieldid = 7 and userid = mdl_user_info_data.userid ) as state, (select data from mdl_user_info_data a where fieldid = 8 and userid = mdl_user_info_data.userid ) as zip, mdl_user.country FROM mdl_certificate_issues INNER JOIN mdl_user_info_data ON mdl_certificate_issues.userid = mdl_user_info_data.userid INNER JOIN mdl_certificate ON mdl_certificate_issues.certificateid = mdl_certificate.id INNER JOIN mdl_course ON mdl_certificate_issues.certificateid = mdl_course.id INNER JOIN mdl_user on mdl_certificate_issues.userid = mdl_user.id INNER JOIN mdl_grade_grades on mdl_certificate_issues.userid = mdl_grade_grades.id

Forum Post: 
Post title: Report to determine how long it takes before a student's assignment is graded
Post description: HI, I asked in another forum before I realized that there was an analytics and reporting forum so I am asking here in hopes that someone can steer me in the right direction. RE: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=239747 I need to run a report to find out how long it takes between the time a student submits any sort of human-gradable assignment and the time it is graded so that we can monitor our staff's efficiency. Right now I am going for a query similar to the one below. I still need to add in the actual assignments but I am not sure which items in moodle could possibly fit into the "submitted but waiting to be graded" category. Which tables am I missing for this query and is there anything I am obviously doing wrong here? I am relatively new to moodle but not new to programing or SQL . 
```text
SELECT c.shortname AS course_name
     , cm.id AS cmid
     , cm.course AS courseid
     , md.name AS modname
     , gi.itemname AS itemname
     , u.firstname AS student_first
     , u.lastname AS student_last
     , f.firstname AS grader_first
     , f.lastname AS grader_last
     , NULLIF(GREATEST(IFNULL(g.overridden, 0)
                      ,IFNULL(g.timecreated, 0)
                      ,IFNULL(g.timemodified, 0))
             ,0) AS graded_unixtimestamp
  
  FROM mdl_user u
  JOIN mdl_user_enrolments ue
    ON (u.id = ue.userid)
  JOIN mdl_enrol e
    ON (e.id = ue.enrolid)
  JOIN mdl_course c
    ON (c.id = e.courseid)
  JOIN mdl_course_modules cm
    ON (c.id = cm.course)
  JOIN mdl_modules md
    ON (md.id = cm.module)
  JOIN mdl_grade_items gi
    ON (
        gi.itemmodule = md.name
        AND 
        gi.iteminstance = cm.instance
        AND gi.courseid = cm.course)
  LEFT
  JOIN mdl_grade_grades g
    ON (gi.id = g.itemid AND g.userid = u.id)
  LEFT
  JOIN mdl_user f
    ON (g.usermodified = u.id)
```

One of the challenges that I have been set is to get Moodle to generate a report on students engagement with their Moodle courses. The aim is to use this data to highlight, as early as possible, students that are "at risk" of dropping out or failing their course. I understand that some custom reports may have to be built but I would appreciate any advice from the Moodle Community on what sort of data should I collect and indeed any other advice that you deem relevant. Thanks in advance Mark

Forum Post: 
Post title: Suggestion: Alternative logs for fast, efficient reports
Post description: Hi everybody, I hope I'm in the right forum. I have an idea for another log system and would appreciate your opinion. We have a need for periodical reports that will give basic statistics for the activities in a course, showing the number of views, updates etc. As of now, the usual approach is running through mdl_log and selecting all records that match the selected course and time period. Problem is, our site contains over Hundred of courses and thousands of users and the result is a huge amount of data that even after regular backup and cleaning is still very heavy. One of the ideas is to create a new log table that will contain much less data and will be used for basic information. Now for some technical stuff... The table structure is very simple: id, time, course, module, view_counter, add_counter, edit_counter, delete_counter The first four values are similar to those in mdl_log and the rest are simple counters. The idea is that while the usual add_to_log function collects user, time, ip and so on, this table will contain the activities counters for every module. Another difference is the the time field will not contain the current time but the current month . This way one record will hold information for a single course module for a whole month (or a whole week, depends on the need). The advantage is a very fast, very target specific statistical tool that will show the different activities in one or several courses over a period of time, pointing out the less used instances and so on. However, there are some serious disadvantages. The developer will need to go through all the places in the modules that call to add_to_log and add near it a call to the new log [ for example: log_action(courseid, moduletype, actiontype) ] While add_to_log just add a new record, here there is a need to look for a record by specific time, course and module values in order to update it. On one hand, this table will be relatively small to work with, but on the other hand it will be called constantly from every page. And this is the major problem here. I looked for similar issues and didn't find anything close enough so I don't know if a similar idea has been discussed here before. If so, I'll be happy if someone will direct me there.
Label:

Post title: Moodle Statistics report processing start time?
Post description: The documentation for Moodle's Statistics report says: TIP: Set the stats processing to start an hour before your automated course backups are scheduled to start, then set the maximum runtime to 1 hour. This ensures that stats are not being processed at the same time as course backups are being made. However, the settings in Server » Statistics don't seem to include any settings related to specifying when the statistics processing will run (only how long it will run for and the amount of data to process). Is this something that it is now no longer necessary to set explicitly? (We are running Moodle 4.5)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It might be referring to the Cron jobs (Admin - Server - Tasks - Scheduled Tasks): there is a task for "Background processing for statistics (\core\task\stats_cron_task)"?
Comment 2: Thanks - well found! (Although it looks like I won't actually need to change any settings: from the logs accessible via that page it looks as though the statistics report only takes a few seconds to run, so that hopefully rules it out as a potential cause of server load for us.)

Post title: Reporting and dashboard: Power BI or Superset ?
Post description: Hi all, I know that I posed a very big question but I need some indications from some of you that have already experienced the use of one of the two instruments to make ad hoc reports and dashboard using Moodle API in order to have some better reports than the ones proposed by Moodle inside it. Some of the reports could be: Enrollment Trends : A line chart showing the number of enrollments over time for each course. Grade Distribution : A bar chart displaying the distribution of grades for each student in a selected course. Quiz Scores : A table showing the average quiz scores for each student in a selected course. Discussion Forum Activity : A heatmap visualizing the frequency and timing of discussion posts for each student in a selected course. Completion Course : A table showing the users completed the course and every single course activity. User's Learning Path :  show the courses he/she completed during the years Etc. etc. Any help or link to deepen the issue is very very appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I use PowerBi but most because is the one that my company use... Use one or the other, look to get the database diagram for your moodle version, it helps a lot when you recreate the relations.
Comment 2: Hello Nicola Vallinoto! 😊 I completely understand how detailed reports can transform the management and analysis experience on an educational platform. First of all, I want to say that you're on the right track by exploring tools like Power BI and Superset, but let me introduce you to a solution that was created specifically for Moodle: Kopere BI . Kopere BI is an open-source plugin I developed with care, specifically designed to provide advanced reports and interactive dashboards for Moodle. It connects directly to Moodle's database and offers a user-friendly interface for creating custom reports. Installation is super simple, and you can access the repository on GitHub here: https://github.com/EduardoKrausME/moodle-local_kopere_bi , while Moodle.org reviews its approval for the store. If you need help configuring it or creating specific reports, just reach out! We're here to help and make Moodle even more powerful for you and your team! 🚀 Eduardo Kraus Teacher and Developer
Comment 3: Thanks Miguel for the suggestion. Sure I will take db diagram to recreate relationships. Looking around there are many experiences with Power BI but no one with Superset.
Comment 4: Hi Eduardo, your work seem very interesting in particular way because you are also a teacher and know very well what is needed. I would like to try your plugin. I have Moodle version 4.1. Is it ok ? Nicola
Comment 5: Hi Nicola, I currently use Google Looker Studio. It allows you to connect directly to the Moodle database, run custom SQL queries, and visualize the results through interactive dashboards. With this approach, you can create all the reports you mentioned—enrollment trends, grade distributions, quiz scores, course completions, learning paths, and more—tailored exactly to your needs. This is a dashboard I created https://campuscivet.ar/dashboardacademia.html
Comment 6: We've had success with both Power BI, Apache Superset, and Tableau. It's usually dictated by the client. If you are interested in the analytics of Moodle, I'd recommend getting the Logstore xAPI plugin along with an LRS like SQL LRS . Both of them are free and open source. You will get a TON more data from Moodle and in an easier/faster format than interacting with the Moodle API/DB.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Time spent in course with Mobile App
Post description: Hi, Referring to this discussion https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=441131 User's accumulative time spent in course Which uses this code https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports?_gl=1*1550key*_ga*MTAzNzQ0MzMzOS4xNzMyMDIwMzg1*_ga_QWYJYEY9P5*MTc0NDAyMzUxMS4yMS4xLjE3NDQwMjM5ODQuMC4wLjA.#User.27s_accumulative_time_spent_in_course Which is working for me. But is there a better, more efficient way to know how much time a student spent in a course if he is only using the Moodle mobile app? I have found that the logs for web based access vs webservices (app) are very different. You might have only one record for clicking on a page of an assignment if you access with a web browser but several api requests if you are doing it by mobile. Is there a native, more efficient way of knowing how much time a certain student has spent with the mobile app open on a certain Moodle course? Best,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In general, you will never know how much "time" students spend doing anything, even reading the textbook, because you cannot account for "breaks." The mobile app on an iPhone can be opened, but then the student can switch to messaging, answer a phone call, browse the Internet, or many other things. And even if the student opens the Moodle app, leaves it open, but reads a book, how does one calculate time? That query seems to make some assumptions about time, as do other LMSs. I just don't think you can get any accurate picture of "time." This question about "time spent in course" always makes me wonder, "Why?" A student who is a speed reader might read textbook chapter in 30 minutes, whereas the slow reading student takes 2 hours. What does it matter? Your question is asked frequently, so if you do a little more searching, you will find many more discussions about "time on ... (activity, video, LMS, SCORM , etc.)" The Canvas LMS provides a "time in course" statistic.  Lots of folks like it.  However, I explored this in depth with the Canvas data experts and found that they knew, just as I knew, that it is a completely bogus calculation.  It errs on the high side, which makes it seem like students are spending a lot of time in Canvas.  This seems to help sell the Canvas LMS.  But again, it's a bogus statistic.
Comment 2: Hi Rick, I agree with you 200%! And I remind also people at my University that you can have your window in the browser open and simply listen to music while watching birds flying outside. But it is a requirement. So with the explicit assumption that counting intervals between clicks in the web-browser equals "time studying". Does the mobile app have an internal native counter that you can query, that measures how much time the app was the one active/maximixed on your phone? (I use Samsung, so I don't know about Iphone, but you can only have one app in the screen at any particular moment, even though they can run in the background. Best,
Comment 3: A query can be set up to gather how many times a student has accessed Moodle. This begins with the logstore_standard_log table, but then you must join it with a few other tables to get students' names, etc. Then, you get to make your own assumptions about how much time a student spends on your Moodle when they "click in." Let's say, 5 minutes. If you don't like what you see, you can adjust to 5 minutes to any value that you want until you get something that looks good to you. I am unsure if the logstore_standard_log table has some data in it to capture if the click was from a mobile device. Perhaps someone else will know.
Comment 4: While I agree that each estimate of time-on-task is flawed, I don't consider it to be a meaningless statistic. However, determining accuracy is not straightforward. The simplest approach would be to sum the duration of specific events recorded in the log table, but the situation is more complex than it first appears. The most advanced - at least to my knowledge - estimation of time-on-task using Moodle data is presented in the works of Daniela Rotelli: Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (n.d.). A Data Science Perspective on Online Student Temporal Learning Patterns and Dynamics . Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (2021). Making Sense of Moodle Log Data (Version 4). arXiv. https://doi.org/10.48550/ARXIV.2106.11071 Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (2022). Time-on-Task Estimation by data-driven Outlier Detection based on Learning Activities . LAK22: 12th International Learning Analytics and Knowledge Conference , 336–346. https://doi.org/10.1145/3506860.3506913 Rotelli, D., & Monreale, A. (2023). Processing and Understanding Moodle Log Data and Their Temporal Dimension. Journal of Learning Analytics , 10 (2), Article 2. https://doi.org/10.18608/jla.2023.7867 Hope this helps. But don't blame me that I sent you down the rabbit hole.
Comment 5: I am not blaming you for making me look at these articles. I understand how publishing in journals is important to some. I might say, "Rotelli and Monreal have done a good job squeezing four journal articles out of one theme," but so what? The bottom line is that Moodle records clicks, not time. So you don't know. There is no "duration" field in the log table to sum. Consider a Moodle quiz. In the quiz results, Moodle shows when the quiz was started and when it was ended. You might want to calculate that a student spent 32 minutes on a quiz by subtracting start time from end time. But you don't know what the student really did between these two times. Did they take a 10 minute break? Who knows. And you can't even conclude anything about how fast a student finished a quiz. Is the faster student smarter? Or is the student who spent more time on the quiz the smarter student (perhaps because they know not to rush). The quiz results tell you much more than time tells you. I actually once did this analysis, in my "Business Analytics" course. I plotted exam results against time and ended up with no correlation.
Comment 6: Thank you Rick and Jerz.

Post title: MAX(CASE problem with ad-hoc reporting
Post description: I'm working on optimising some of our more complex queries and have run into an issue. I have a query which works correctly when used directly through MySQL workbench but results in a 'page not found' when attempting to run through ad-hoc reporting. It works fine until MAX() is wrapped around the CASE statements. Does anyone have any ideas on this? Is it a known featur? Is there a workaround? attached is a simplified version created for testing which again works correctly within MY SQL Workbench Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Does this work for you? (I don't have access to Workbench to test it...) `SELECT` `mu.username,` `ui.manager,` `ui.Organisation,` `ui.Unit,` `ui.Region,` `ui.Area,` `ui.Branch` `FROM {user} mu` `LEFT JOIN (` `SELECT` `uid.userid,` `MAX(CASE WHEN uif.shortname = 'manager' THEN uid.data END) AS manager,` Or this: `SELECT` `mu.username,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'manager') AS manager,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l3') AS Organisation,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l4') AS Unit,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l5') AS Region,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l6') AS Area,` `(SELECT MAX(uid.data)` `FROM {user_info_data} uid` `JOIN {user_info_field} uif ON uid.fieldid = uif.id` `WHERE uid.userid = mu.id AND uif.shortname = 'l7') AS Branch` `FROM {user} mu` `WHERE mu.deleted = 0 AND mu.suspended = 0` `AND mu.username = '20001143'`

Post title: Moodle logs participants filter not showing those not part of a group
Post description: Hello, In a Moodle environment where the course-level group mode is set to 'Visible groups,' participants who haven't been assigned to any group are not appearing in the Participants filter on the Moodle logs screen. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes, this behavior has been observed in Moodle for some time. When group mode is set to 'Visible groups,' users who aren't assigned to any group often don't appear in the Participants filter on the Moodle logs screen. This is likely by design, as the filter is intended to show only those participants tied to specific groups.
Comment 2: Hello, you say it can be by design but all other drop-down menus in Report/log page select for "all" (the whole) by default. If "All participants" is not really listing all participants but some, this isn't quite consistent and this is confusing for teachers and admin. Otherwise, there is a separate "All group" menu that allow to filter for one group. As a result, participants not belonging to any group (teachers and students) can't be selected to filter logs results when the course is in "visible groups" or "separate group" mode ("no group" is OK). For me, it's an issue. I create one in the tracker : https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-84514 Regards, Marina

Post title: Following content deletions, how can I check/confirm my Moodle's performance has improved
Post description: Hi there, I hope you're well (and that I'm asking in the right place). I'd like to ask about the best ways to check and/or test that my Moodle's performance has improved following the deletion of a significant amount of (old) content; ideally, the specific logs/reports etc I should check that indicate user performance has improved or worsened. Kind regards, Ron A
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In order to know one would have to have some data before you embarked upon that goal of improving performance.   There is an addon called 'Benchmark' that, if you had that installed previously you could now compare past benchmarks with current. If you have command line access and can install software and on Linux, I'd recommend installing My SQL Tuner - a perl script.  Run it with super user creds for your DB server .  It has recommendations for improving performance of the DB server.   Works with MariaDB as well. While there are areas for tweaking for better performance, I think the DB server config is gonna give you improvements in performance of the site. Of course there are things you've not shared ... how are you hosted?   On shared hosting or dedicated VPS?  Moodle version? (and thus PHP version as well as MySQL /MariaDB version) etc. 'SoS', Ken

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to track deletion of Course Modules?
Post description: Hello everyone, I’ve been exploring Moodle’s data tracking, particularly the way it logs changes within courses. While I see that the creation of course modules (files) is logged, I noticed that deletions aren’t. It would be really useful to track all changes, including deletions, for a complete course history. Does anyone know if there are configuration options to enable logging of deletions? Or maybe plugins that would capture this information? Any advice would be greatly appreciated! Thanks, Luke
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, Lucas! 😊 Unfortunately, Moodle does not register module deletions by default, which can be a bit frustrating, especially for those who want a complete history of course changes. However, I have a suggestion for you: this feature, to track deletions, needs to be in the core of Moodle, but you can submit a request to have it implemented directly in MoodleHQ. To do so, simply access the following link: https://tracker.moodle.org/ , and if you don’t have an account there yet, you’ll need to create one. Once you access it, check if there is already a similar request. If not, you can open a new "Feature Request," explaining that you would like an option to track module deletions, with details of who made the change and when. The clearer your request, the more likely it is to be noticed and possibly implemented in the next version of Moodle. For sure, if everyone contributes suggestions on the tracker, Moodle will become even better! I hope this solution helps you, and if you have any other questions, I’m here to help! 😊 Eduardo Kraus Teacher and programmer

Forum Post: 
Post title: Clear definition of activity columns statsreads and statswrites
Post description: Hey everyone, At our university, we've been analyzing student activity data across several courses. Our Moodle administrator (we’re currently on Moodle 4.x, I believe version 4.2) provided us with a dataset containing monthly aggregates of student activity. This dataset includes the following columns: id : student identifier courseid : course identifier date : month and year statsreads : integer statswrites : integer Each row represents one student’s activity in a course for a given month, with `statsreads` and `statswrites` representing aggregated actions. However, our administrator couldn’t specify which activities contribute to the `statsreads` and `statswrites` metrics. The site Examulator maps Moodle's relational database (if that’s the correct term) and displays the variables we’re referencing. After some research, we found a few sources that give a vague definition of `statsreads` and `statswrites` : Moodle Docs suggest that in the Stats package, "reads" and "writes" correspond to "view" and "post" actions ( source ). A similar question was asked in the Moodle forum, but no clear answer was provided ( source ). We checked Moodle’s source code on GitHub, but lines 1299–1305 don’t clarify which activities are counted, for example, as "view" ( source ). Penny Leach’s 2005 forum post offers a general definition but lacks specifics ( source ). Are there any official sources that clarify what activities `statsreads` and `statswrites` measure? We don’t need a comprehensive list of every single activity, but a better understanding of what qualifies as, for example, a "view" would be incredibly helpful. If you have any questions, please feel free to ask. I’ll respond as quickly as I can. Thanks for reading, and best wishes, Luis

Forum Post: 
Post title: Activity report showing less users than completion report for same time frame
Post description: Hello I'm currently have moodle version 3.11. I create reports showing how many users have accessed a course page in a set time frame and I compare this with how many users have completed a scorm course on the same page. I use the activity report on Moodle to filter user numbers and I download a progress report to gather completion data. For one course there are more completers than users in the same time frame. I have double checked the data using logs and there are no duplicates. I don't understand why the activity report is showing a lower number. Is using activity reporting data unsound? Thanks for your help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I understand your confusion with the discrepancies between the activity report and the completion report in Moodle. It can be frustrating when the numbers don’t add up. One common reason for this issue is that some users might complete the SCORM activity without actually accessing the course page. For example, they could have accessed it directly through a link or bookmark, which might not register in the activity report. In general, while the activity report is a useful tool, it’s important to understand its limitations and how it tracks user engagement versus completion. It might be helpful to review the tracking settings in your SCORM package as well to ensure everything is being recorded as expected.
Comment 2: Hi Giorgio Thanks for your post. I've worked it out and thought I'd share this in case it affects others. I'd updated some Scorm files to show a change in completion percentage. When I uploaded the files to Moodle it changed the status of past users who had nearly completed.  This resulted in more completers than users in a particular time frame. The evidence could be found in the system log. Kat

Forum Post: 
Post title: No statistics available
Post description: Hi all, I just realized there are no statistics available on our moodle 4.2.1 website. All I get is "Sorry, there is no available data to display" and a link to the docs . This is true for the site statictics ( /report/stats/index.php ) as well as for the individual course statictics ( /report/stats/index.php?course=<id> ). This is what I checked: Statistics have been enabled since yesterday ( enablestats on admin/settings.php?section=optionalsubsystems ). All options are set to default ( statsfirstrun , statsmaxruntime , statsruntimedays , and statsuserthreshold on admin/settings.php?section=stats ). The job "Background processing for statistics" ( \core\task\stats_cron_task ) ran at midnight for 35 seconds (success; 59 reads; 16s writes). I also ran it manually two hours ago from /admin/tool/task/scheduledtasks.php (success; 0 reads; 4 writes) . The docs mention a potential problem with missing files in the moodle/mod folder. I'm not sure what "If you find any, they should be deleted" means exactly. I don't see any messages about missing files in the browser window, however. There are log entries for each course going back several months. The cronjob should generate statistics from these entries, right? Thanks Oliver
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ensure that the required statistics tables in your Moodle database are set up correctly. Sometimes, missing or corrupted tables can lead to this issue. Verify that there’s enough recent activity in your courses to generate meaningful statistics. Since you mentioned months of log entries, there should be enough data, but it’s good to double-check. Since you’ve already run the stats cron job manually, make sure that it’s scheduled to run at an appropriate frequency in your site’s cron settings. Look into the Moodle logs for any errors or warnings related to statistics processing. That might give you more context on what’s going wrong. The mention of missing files usually refers to certain plugins or modules that may not be fully installed or could be corrupt. Check if all standard Moodle modules are present in your /mod folder.
Comment 2: Thank you! We did all the things you recommend back in May. That didn't seem to help at first, but a few days or weeks after my original post, statistics going back four weeks were available. Since then we have not looked at the issue, but now I have checked again: Stats are now available for the last five months. I've just changed statsfirstrun from three months to “none” and I'm curious to see if the time period will continue to grow.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Session Timeout Logout Report
Post description: Hello, we using moodle 4.2 and have issues with reporting. In our organization reporting is very important. We have to report when a user is loged in, and when is loged out. Unfortunately the loged out user not working except ONLY if a user is actually hitting the button "Log Out", which, in practice did not happening that much. We would be ok, if the session timeout actually make an entry in the report, but that is missing. Is there any way to make "log out" entry of a user due inactivity? Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I understand how crucial accurate reporting is for your organization, especially regarding user activity in Moodle. Unfortunately, as you've noticed, Moodle typically only logs a user as "logged out" when they actively click the "Log Out" button. This can be a challenge since many users may not log out manually. One workaround is to adjust the session timeout settings. While Moodle doesn’t automatically log users out due to inactivity in a way that generates a report entry, you can set a shorter session timeout. This way, users will be logged out more frequently, and you might capture more accurate data in your reports.
Comment 2: How about a .txt file 'report'? If you want totals, here's one way: A command line script to get activity for 24 hour period. (I use passwordless for DB CLI query so you don't see the -p option below): get24hr - contents mysql -u root -e "use moodle;select userid,action,other,ip,realuserid,origin,ip,timecreated from mdl_logstore_standard_log WHERE timecreated > UNIX_TIMESTAMP(NOW() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR);" > 24hours.txt; cat 24hours.txt|more; wc -l 24hours.txt That outputs to a 24hours.txt file and the wc gives total number of hits. Then, one can: fgrep 'loggedon' 24hours.txt |wc -l to get a total count on hits of those that logged on. And to get a total count of hits of those that logged out. If you wanted to keep a daily, one could add a date/time stamp to the name of the 24hours.txt file by adding -$(date +%Y%m%d%-H%M) making the name of the 24hours.txt file 24hours-$(date +%Y%m%d%-H%M).txt You could set up a cron job to do the above every 24 hours. Not logging out is a bad habit.  Have concluded that might be encouraged by the  way resources/files are linked to in courses.   If those links replace the moodle screen users forget they are logged on and simply close that window when they are done ... thus moodles session clean up eventually would force user to login again due to inactivity. 'SoS', Ken

Post title: SQL queries to help with at-risk students
Post description: As the subject suggests I am trying to figure out queries that can help with identifying and providing on-time support for at-risk.The questions that I am trying to answer are: How many courses have an gradebook associated with it? If there is a record in the grade_outcomes table, this means a grade-book was setup? How frequently do faculty members update grades in the Moodle Gradebook? What is the average number of visits to the Moodle Gradebook per student? This helps answer when a student last logged into a course, but we don’t know if there is logging when a user accesses the gradebook to view their grades. At what point in time do professors begin setting up their courses in Moodle? What columns/variables would help answer these questions? Any insights, comments or feedback would be appreciated. TY for your time.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Moodle community. Any help and feedback with this request would be helpful. Using Moodle 4.1. Thank you!
Comment 2: Your questions don't quite match your subject, but I will give you some thoughts. 1) By default, all courses have a grade book. 2) The grade book could be updated automatically by quizzes, so your question doesn't make sense. Might you explain why knowing this is relevant? 3) You might be able to get to this with a custom SQL query. But why is this relevant? 4) Consider that the Moodle admin creates a course. The instructor clicks on the course to see that it is "alive." Is this what you mean by "setting up?" If so, you are then more interested in "first access." After the first access, a professor might create a quiz on one day, and another quiz on another day. So there is no "point" in time. You might need to define what you mean by "setting up."

Post title: Extending the Event Monitoring system
Post description: The event monitoring system in Moodle has a lot of promise, but also a lot of limitations. The same is true for the ad hoc database query tool.  Ideally, I'd love to be able to run a query and have the results automatically emailed to me, but ONLY if the query returned a result.  Like right now if I set up a query to run daily in the ad hoc db query tool on a daily basis, it does the query and then emails me the result, even if the result is "This query did not return any data." What I want to do is set up some alerts that would trigger if certain conditions were true. For example, if the enrloment in any course goes above 100 students, I'd like it send me an alert.  Is there an easy way to do that? Or do I need to modify the ad hoc db query tool?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Take a look at our dataflows plugin: - it allows you to listen to events, then trigger lookups to get more information then action on the data that it can access: https://github.com/catalyst/moodle-tool_dataflows it's not in the plugins db yet - particularly because the documentation is a bit sparse and it needs a bit of playing around - it's loosely based on our older tool_trigger plugin (which is in the plugins db, but if you're first starting out - try the dataflows one instead.)
Comment 2: Nice!. I considered recommending trigger. I will look at dataflows.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Course Usage Information
Post description: We're interested in getting an idea of how many shells we created each term actually end up getting used by faculty.  Using database queries and the "Moodle Usage Statistics" plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/report_modstats ) I'm able to see, for example, the number of courses by category that have assignment activities .  The idea being courses without Assignments aren't being used.  This is helpful but not an entirely accurate assumption, however, since some faculty might simply use Moodle as a way to share files or links or as a launch point for an external tool. Another idea I had was identifying what a 'default' shell size is to ID courses not being used (aka, not having content uploaded) using the course size plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/report_coursesize ).  This plugin can inflate course sizes and this fails to account for courses that don't have file uploads increasing the disk footprint and instead rely on other activities. Another idea was to find a course last modified date.  Moodle's course table has this, but my understanding is this only records when changes via the course Settings menu have been saved.  This wouldn't track changes to the course like adding a file or modifying an assignment, for example.  There doesn't seem to be a universal last modified value for a course in the database. Has anyone found solutions to gathering usage data either through plugins or database queries that I might be missing?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I haven't detected from what you posted what you mean when you say, "end up getting used by faculty."  For example, do you mean that a faculty enters the course x times per day?  Or do you mean the faculty forces students to use the system?  Or do you mean that the faculty is modifying due dates?  Or is " upload " content" what you are looking for versus modifying content? As an idea, might it be that you are interested in how often the particular faculty "enters the course?"  Or how many resources and assignments are turned on for students? When one speaks about faculty or student "activity," I always wonder what they mean.  Also, I wonder about why "number of times" is important.  An "efficient" faculty or student might only need to access a course (like once) each week.
Comment 2: I'm looking for ways I can approximate what percentage of courses created for a given term are never utilized. My organization wants faculty to use Moodle. Not all faculty use it. So I'm attempting to identify a method to gather this information. I don't care who the faculty not using it are, I just want to see the data related to courses or activities. As I mentioned in my initial post, I have a percentage of courses that never get an assignment activity added. Obviously, not all faculty are going to use Moodle in the same way. Some might rely of other activity types. Some might simply post files or links. Others might only use an external LTI tool. I'm simply asking if others have experience attempting to identify this or similar information from Moodle's DB or if there are reporting tools that address these issues.
Comment 3: Consider creating a custom SQL query. Perhaps one is already created in Ad-hoc contributed report . In "English," the query would be something like, "Show me how many times all courses were accessed."  For further refinement, you might say "by the person with instructor role." I took a quick look at the contributed reports, and I do see one query that might work for you, "Most active courses."  I also see a report for "Least active or probably empty courses."
Comment 4: Hi Stephen, You can also obtain course usage information from the course overview report which is available in standard Moodle if you enable Statistics on your site. For details, see the documentation Course overview report .
Comment 5: I tried your suggestion, Helen, and it works! This report provides a few different ways to look at course activity. So much will depend upon what Stephen considers "activity," but the course overview report is one quick way to get some statistics.
Comment 6: Thank you for the suggestion. I think custom database queries are going to be the better option in my case.

Forum Post: 
Post title: SQL query to show grade breakdown as percentages
Post description: Evening all. I'm new to Moodle and MySQL and hoping I can get some help with a query I've written.  I'm looking to create a report to show all the assignments per unit, and for each one the percentage of students who received a pass, merit or distinction as well as the percentage of students who have needed to resubmit. I've written the below, and it is showing the assignment names, pass, merit and distinction percentages.  However, it's not showing the correct unit IDs and the resubmission percentage is always showing as 0 which isn't correct as some students have needed to resubmit. Can someone maybe give me some insight into where I'm going wrong? SELECT gi.courseid AS unit_ID, a.name AS assignment_name, COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) AS total_submissions, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 3.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS pass_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 4.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS merit_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN gg.finalgrade = 5.000 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS distinction_percentage, LEAST(100, ROUND((SUM(CASE WHEN g.attemptnumber = 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / COUNT(DISTINCT s.id) * 100))) AS resubmission_percentage FROM {assign} AS a LEFT JOIN {assign_submission} AS s ON a.id = s.assignment LEFT JOIN {assign_grades} AS g ON s.id = g.assignment JOIN {grade_grades} AS gg ON s.userid = gg.userid INNER JOIN {grade_items} AS gi ON gg.itemid = gi.id GROUP BY gi.courseid, a.name
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: join grade_items to assign using the itemtype, itemmodule and iteminstance settings

Post title: Aggregating/Filtering User Analytics
Post description: I'm helping to manage a Moodle environment to support teacher professional development. I'd be interested to learn if there is a straightforward way to: Generate a report that aggregates enrollment and completion data for all users across the platform, with the results filterable by specific fields in a user's profile taht include: School District County State Administrators at each level should only be able to see data relevant to the level for which they are responsible. E.g., A school leader should only be able to see the course enrollment for teachers at their school but not other schools. A District Admin should be able to see data for teachers who work at schools within their district but not for teachers who work outside of their district Thanks for pointing me to any how-to's/plugins on pulling something like this off. -Steve
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Is a bit of work, but for the reports you can make different queries in SQL using WHERE to filter different school, district, etc. as you need. For the other matter, the administrators are global, but you can assign course managers, so if you filter the courses for areas and assign the same managers to them (so they have only will access for that courses), is not perfect but something similar to that you are asking. Hope this help you.

Post title: Ad-hoc database queries plugin complains at reusing one parameter twice in the query
Post description: I was trying to create a custom report where I parse the file from the URL like this: 
```text
    SELECT CONCAT('https',CHAR(58),'//example.com/report.php',CHAR(63),'contentID=',l.contentID)
    FROM {reporter_links} l
    JOIN {files} f
    ON l.fileid = f.id
    WHERE f.contextid = (SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX((SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX(:url, '/', 5)), '/', -1))
    AND f.itemid=(SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX((SELECT SUBSTRING_INDEX(:url, '/', 8)), '/', -1))
    AND f.filename != '.'
```
 This is the error I get: 
```text
Error when executing the query: ERROR: Incorrect number of query parameters. Expected 2, got 1.
```
 I figured out that reusing :url is the culprit. The horrible workaround was to introduce :url2 and paste the link twice in the report GUI. Is there any other way to solve this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Martin, This is more a limitation of the underlying database drivers than anything specific to that plugin In fact it appears the same thing was requested already: https://github.com/moodleou/moodle-report_customsql/issues/96

Forum Post: 
Post title: Tracking question completion time in quizzes
Post description: Hello, Is there a table on the moodle DB that can track question completion time for each question in a given quiz? I have tried looking into mdl_quiz_attempts and mdl_question_attempts and while the first one shows me completion time for each quiz I cannot seem to find the same in question_attempts. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I might be wrong, but the Moodle database does not keep track of every keystroke within a quiz question. If every quiz question is on its own separate page, meaning that the "Next" button is used, they database might keep track of this. I would start exploring this by looking at the logstore table. So, a student is presented a multiple choice question. They click on choice A, then change their mind, and click on choice B. After answering other questions, they return to this one and click choice C. Or, they return to this question, look at it, and do nothing. I think you would want all time on this question, right? And if more than one question is on a page, how would you determine which question the student is reconsidering? Perhaps the desire to get 'time per question" could only be possible if only one question is shown per page.

Post title: Moodle 4.0, trying to get a custom relational report that crosses users and course
Post description: Good morning everyone, on Moodle 4.0, we are trying to get a custom report (example: for the activity of reading pdf file, Person 1, when he did activity start log and activity close log, so the total duration in which he was active on that activity is X minutes) the information we want to see contained in the downloadable report is: 1) login date and time 2) logout date and time 3) session duration 4) title of the course 5) name of the activity 6) name of participant 7) email address 8) identification code the Report Builder plugin has been installed to allow us to display custom reports by querying the database with the information we need, but apparently it does not seem possible to relate the Users database to the Courses database, so we need a relational report that crosses identifiable users and course with related activities + session duration for each activity (for each individual). How can this be done to resolve this issue? Sorry if this may be a topic already covered, but I have not yet found answers to our needs. Thank you very much.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Zenit, YOu can use the following approach to connect users with their courses. FROM prefix_course_categories AS cat JOIN prefix_course AS mc ON mc.category = cat.id JOIN prefix_context AS context ON context.instanceid = mc.id JOIN prefix_role_assignments AS ra ON ra.contextid = context.id JOIN prefix_user mu ON ra.userid = mu.id But I am unsure if this way of approaching the time students spend in the course or activity will give you accurate results. Best wishes Mo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ad-Hoc Report: New Enrolments in the Last 24 hours
Post description: Hi, folks, I'm looking for a little help constructing an SQL statement for the Ad-Hoc Report tool that returns New Enrolments in the Last 24 hours.  Fields I'm looking for... course.idnumber course.shortname u.firstname u.lastname u.email enrolment date (UNIXTIME(cc.timeenrolled) ?) <24 hours from now WHERE course.idnumber LIKE 'UILX%' I'd really appreciate it if someone who had mastered SQL could help me write this query. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've made some progress but got stuck again. When I reduce the time frame from 48 hours (in the code below) to 24 hours the number of records returned comes to just 2. There have been way more enrolments in the last 24 hours than that. 
```text
SELECT DISTINCT user2.firstname AS Firstname,
    user2.lastname AS Lastname,
    user2.email AS Email,
    course.shortname AS CourseName,
    role.shortname as Role,
    FROM_UNIXTIME(ue.timestart) AS enrolment_date
FROM prefix_course as course
JOIN prefix_enrol AS en ON en.courseid = course.id
JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON ue.enrolid = en.id
JOIN prefix_user AS user2 ON ue.userid = user2.id
JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = user2.id
JOIN prefix_role role ON ra.roleid = role.id
WHERE course.idnumber LIKE 'UILX%' AND ue.timestart >= (UNIX_TIMESTAMP() - 172800) 
ORDER BY course.shortname
```
Comment 2: Here is how I would query for new students within the last 24 hours, shown below. However, I see that you want to also know what course(s) they are in. Yep, it gets a bit more complex. Are they enrolled in any courses? Do you want to include suspended users? And are they only students, or teachers, etc. Perhaps my simple query will help you think through your needs. Also, if a student created their account but didn't enroll in a course, my query below probably won't answer your question. I am just trying to help you think about this. SELECT firstname, https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports

Forum Post: 
Post title: Comparison of Adaptive vs deferred feedback analytics
Post description: Hello Moodle community, I have been trialing the adaptive mode in quizzes in my large 1st year course. I would like to have some sort of comparison of how this has benefitted students, but what I thought I could do is not working. My thinking was to look at the quiz statistics and calculate on first attempt or first try, vs last attempt/last try, but this makes no difference. I then tried changing the quiz to 'deferred' feedback and regrading, but htis made no change. Is there a way to do this? kind regards Gareth
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Gareth, Answers on a first try in adaptive mode and answers in deferred feedback mode shouldn't differ much, in principle, since it's a first try and a single try, which is about the same. Obviously, answers on the last try in adaptive mode should normally be better than on the first try or in deferred feedback mode. In general, the adaptive mode would be more appropriate for formative assessments, while the deferred feedback mode would be more appropriate for summative assessments. Personally, I use the adaptive mode even for summative assessments because I consider that it is of little use for students to be blocked without having any clues, and without having one or more attempts to answer questions. Indeed, in my view, the primary purpose of quizzes, both formative and summative, is for students to learn about a topic. The summative aspect is well taken into account in adaptive mode thanks to the penalties for each try. Better students get more points for answering questions correctly on the first try, while weaker students lose points for answering correctly only on the second or more tries, or for not getting the correct answer even after the number of tries allowed. So, unless I want to do a very strict summative evaluation, which I don't necessarily see the benefit for the students, I don't use the deferred feedback mode. There are obviously a multitude of cases other than mine where the deferred feedback mode is useful.

Post title: SQL help - students who enrolled in a course after a specific date
Post description: I'm using an Ad Hoc query to count how many students accessed courses since a certain date. I also want to limit the user count to students who enrolled in the course after a date. I'm having trouble with the last part - where does Moodle store a user's enrollment date for a course? Here's the query so far: 
```text
SELECT c.id, count(u.id)


FROM prefix_user u


JOIN prefix_user_enrolments ue ON (ue.userid = u.id)


JOIN prefix_enrol en ON (en.id = ue.enrolid)


JOIN prefix_course c ON (c.id = en.courseid)


JOIN prefix_context cx ON (cx.instanceid = c.id AND cx.contextlevel = 50)


LEFT JOIN prefix_user_lastaccess ul ON (ul.courseid = en.courseid AND ul.userid = u.id)


WHERE ul.timeaccess > unix_timestamp('2022-09-01')


AND (SELECT count(1) 


FROM prefix_role_assignments ra 


WHERE ra.userid = u.id AND ra.roleid = (5) AND ra.contextid = cx.id)
 > 0


GROUP by c.id


ORDER by count(u.id) DESC
```
 Thank you so much for any help or insight. I'm very new to this.

Comment 1: Hi, I think you've already the information it's in the table user_enrolments -> timecreated or timestart Dominique.

I wrote an SQL statement which approriately filters the results to only the Category in question. So now I'm trying to set the "automically email results...' value and it only lists my system-wide admins. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Tay You can add any valid Moodle username to the list to email reports to. The pull down list only shows the Administrators. I presume this is to keep the list short. It doesn't show the other usernames, but if you enter them manually, it works. If you choose a username that does not exist, it will complain when you try to save the report. Those users don't need any permissions set at all to get the email. The permissions are only needed for directly accessing the reports via url or the Site admin menu.
Comment 2: I tried to enter it manually (both by username and by email), and it simply won't add them. There is no "complaint" it just won't let them add them at all. Comment 3: Have you set to the 'Run' type from 'On demand' to one of the 'Scheduled' options?
Comment 4: Yes, that is correct. Like I said, I can send it to myself and other admins just fine. But it won't let me send it to anyone else. Comment 5: Here's how I am doing it now: Set up a System level role and set View custom queries report - report/customsql:view to Allow Assign the users you want to get mailed reports to that system role In the report set "Who can access this query" to "Anyone who can view this report (report/customsql:view)" and set the schedule. Then they show up on the list to mail to.
Comment 6: By the way, there is nothing wrong about assigning this permission to the Manager role if that is what you need. But my experience is that when I do, clients always then want to email some reports to folks who are not Managers. So, in the end I always end up creating a separate system level role for this anyway.
Comment 7: Thanks, Randy, that was super helpful and did the trick! I created a system-wide "Analyst" role and it looks like it's going to work great.
Comment 8: Nice! Glad that worked out.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Site wide SQL report last access to course
Post description: Hi guys, I'm new to Moodle can someone help me with the SQL for a site-wide report on the following fields but i should be able to customise the date range. I'm using the configurable reports. Student last access to courses: First name Surname Student Number Email address Last access to course Course
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You can view all kinds of examples of SQL in List of SQL Contributed reports . I started with Randy Thornton's contribution for Last access time of users to a course The basic SQL code looks something like the one below.  You can add more filters and criteria.  For example, the SQL below will show all people in a course instead of "only students." SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.id, u.email, c.fullname, #la.timeaccess, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(la.timeaccess), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "Last access time" FROM mdl_user_lastaccess la JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id = la.userid JOIN mdl_course c ON c.id = la.courseid order by c.id, u.lastname, u.firstname; You can add a "where c.id in (123, 456, 789)" line to limit the selection to specific courses.
Comment 2: Thanks so much is is exactly what I needed excellent! Can you kindly advise how i can add in a filter to search a range month or year?
Comment 3: I would make my life easier by swapping "LAT" for "Last access time". Then the query could become: SELECT u.firstname, u.lastname, u.id, u.email, c.fullname, #la.timeaccess, DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(la.timeaccess), '%Y-%m-%d %H:%i') AS "LAT" FROM mdl_user_lastaccess la JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id = la.userid JOIN mdl_course c ON c.id = la.courseid where c.id = 93610 having LAT between "2022-01" and "2022-03" order by c.id, u.lastname, u.firstname; Of course, you can make the dates be whatever you wish in that "having" line of code. I also added the "where" line for a specific course. However, this new query will only return students who had a LAT between those two dates, which is different from "which students accessed the course between two dates, and what was their access time?" So you have to think about what question you are trying to answer. Perhaps you are seeing how SQL works.
Comment 4: Thanks a lot im certain moodlers will also benefit from this.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Marrying Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development
Post description: Problem: Limited Knowledge of Moodle Hamstrings Quality Course Design and Facilitation Quality course design with Moodle is limited by the familiarity of the designer / instructor who  builds / teaches the course. They often do not know what they need to learn next and do not proactively seek out further professional development with Moodle (without incentives). Instead, they typically 'call someone' to find out how to do something in Moodle because they want 'just-in-time-learning'. Solution: Marry Analytics with Chatbot-Based Professional Development Imagine if we were able to combine learning analytics data from Moodle with a smart, Customer Service chatbot? Example: Just take something simple, like the Moodle Assignement type. We can bring a faculty member on a learning path to iterate improvements to their use of this activity. All of their Moodle Assignments reflect their current knowledge level (Lean Prompt + Grade Points + File Submission). We could run analytics on the common settings for all of the Moodle Assignments in their course and detect that they don't have (1) activity completion checked (2) marking guide setup, (3) accepting online submissions, etc. We could expand the list. But here is the important point: We could create a chatbot to popup with suggestions for their 'Next Challenge' on how to 'Moodle Up' their Moodle Assignments, by, say, adding a Marking Guide to make it easier to grade. As you think about this from a pedagogical standpoint, there are iterative sequences we could bring end-users through: Main Course Page = Cluttered, High Use of Descriptions Showing on Main Page > Using Labels to Chunk and Organize > Learning How to Clean up Main Course Page, create Module Overviews, etc. Assignment Prompts =  Long, exhaustive prose and Links > Creating Headers to Organize > HTML Tips to Reduce Cognitive Overload > Use of Accordions to Organize and Show/Hide Content Multimedia = Low detection of Multimedia in Course > How to add External URL Resource / Embed > How to Embed Videos > How to Organize a Multimedia 'Set' File Downloads = Detecting High Number of Documents on Main Course Page > How to use Moodle Files to chunk downloads with files that go together You all probably know quite a few more possibilities . . . !! Just imagine a little chatbot which pops up every once in awhile with a 'Want to Moodle Up?' box and a suggestion to help you 'Moodle Up' your skills in designing with Moodle. This would create *tremendous* leverage for those of us who provide Moodle support to our end-users. We have plenty of tutorials. We can direct them to take webinars. We can point them to Moodle Academy . But this type of 'scaled' professional development—delivered in a 'just-in-time' way (based on analytics of their actual Moodle habits), would be a powerful way to improve Moodle skills at scale . I also think it would keep end-users in that 'flow state', because it is tailored to their current level—giving them just enough new challenge without overwhelming them. I would love to see Moodle HQ think about something like this for future versions of Moodle. It could even be keyed to integrate with resources on Moodle Academy.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Great suggestion!
Comment 2: It's a nice idea, but between writing the spec, briefing the developers, QA and integration into Moodle Core etc I suspect the financial cost would be between $AU 50K to 100K. That is a wild stab in the dark estimate and I'd be interested to hear alternatives.
Comment 3: This very idea was proposed and worked on in quite a bit of detail at the first US Moodle Moot in 2015 by Michelle Moore, who now of course, works for Moodle US. That original idea was worked out in some detail, but what Moodle HQ did with it was make the User tours feature. They were not ready to do more with it than that at the time. Perhaps now they are.

Forum Post: Post title: Easy Enrolments Plugin - SQL to pull Pass Code (using configurable reports plugin) Post description: Reposted from Enrolment Thread ( Moodle in English: Easy Enrolments Plugin - SQL to pull Pass Code (using configurable reports plugin) ) Sorry this would be better placed here. Hope that is ok. Dear All, I hope everyone is keeping well. I am desperately trying to find the Table/field that would allow me to pull in my SQL course report with the code needed to enter the course using Easy Enrolments. Report method -Configurable reports plugin SQL (tables I have tried Enrol table / enrol - Moodle LMS 3.9 Database schema / Zoola Analytics ) I am after the Enrolment Method - Easy Enrolment Code Current SQL report (sorry not very tidy as a little rusty but might help people if it is ok) ( constructed using the popular ad-hoc contributed reports - MoodleDocs ) Select cat.id as categoryid, cat.name as categoryname, c.id as courseid, c.fullname as FullCourseName, c.shortname as ShortCourseName, c.summary as CourseSummary, c.format as CourseFormat, c.startdate as CourseStartDate, c.enddate as CourseEndDate, c.timecreated as CourseCreatedDate, c.timemodified as CourseLastModified, concat('',c.fullname,'') as courselink, e.enrol AS enrolmethod, e.password as enrolcode From prefix_course AS c JOIN prefix_course_categories as cat on cat.id = c.category JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON e.id = c.id I look forward to hearing your thoughts and a big thank you in advance. Many thanks, K Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: You need to know what the value is for this particular plugin in the en.enrol field. Standard ones are those such as 'manual' and 'self'. Look at that table to fined out what that is. Then you need to then find in what column it stored the code. For example, the Self-enrolment method stores the enrolment key in the column called 'password'. This plugin may store it there or in perhaps one of the various custom values columns. You will have to take a look at that to find them. This report by Séverin will help you with the logic, too. https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Lists_.22Totally_Opened_Courses.22_.28visible.2C_opened_to_guests.2C_with_no_password.29 Comment 2: Hello Randy, You genius thank you. I think I have been staring at it too long. That is right thinking. Thank you that is very much appreciated. I will have a look. I love the reports on that page so will have a look, thank you again. Take care Comment 3: You are welcome. I think that code from Séverin will help you a lot to get your report working. Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Display unix time stamp as a date
Post description: Good day, Still getting my feet wet with PHP, but I am creating a custom report of everything that is searched on our Moodle site. I have created the table to keep track of the logs and the time stamps as a unix time stamp in PHP myadmin my SQL im suing a SELECT * , I could make the format change in the SQL pull with Select DATE(FROM_UNIXTIME(search_time)), but then I have to select all the columns I was hoping to make the format change with PHP instead, I am using the following to add the search time to the display table and it shows properly $row[] = $record->search_time; In trying to make it a legible time stamp for people, I have tried the following //$row[] = $record->date_create(search_time)->format('U'); //$row[] = $record->to_timestamp(search_time); //$row[] = $record->date("Y-m-d\TH:i:s\Z", search_time); //$row[] = $record->gmdate("Y-m-d\TH:i:s\Z", search_time); but I keep getting the 'Exception - Call to undefined method" as an error
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Assuming $record is the result of looping over the SQL query 
```text
foreach ($records as $record) {}
```
 $record would only contain the data from the database table, not any methods (thus the undefined method error). If you want to generate the date in SQL, you can use an alias to return a nicer fieldname you can iterate over. e.g. 
```text
SELECT (DATE(FROM_UNIXTIME(search_time)) searchtime FROM {searchlogtable};
```
 then you can iterate over the results using $result->searchtime If you want to do the conversion in PHP, you can either use the PHP native date('Y-m-d H:m:s', $timestamp) or you could use Moodle's userdate($timestamp) function that will use the standard date/time format used in Moodle. In your code above, it would look something like: 
```text
foreach ($results as $result) {
    $result->search_time = userdate($result->search_time);
}
```
Comment 2: thanks Mark, I did get it to work with the SQL but I did want to learn how to do it in PHP...for practice,
