Post title: difference in timing in completion reports
Post description: Hello to everyone  my name is Giuseppe and I work as system admin for my company. One of my duties is to manage the Moodle server i really like the system and how it works . but we have a strange discrepancies between the reports. I apologize if this has been already solved elsewhere but i was not able to find information on this topic. As i stated in the subject there is a discrepancy in the completion reports. I cannot understand what causes this issue below you will find the differences (report is of coure regarding the same user and the same training) Activity
completion 3/2/2022 10:50 Completed 3/2/2022 10:52 Completed 3/2/2022 11:06 Completed (achieved pass grade) 3/4/2022 9:35 Course completion 2/03/22, 11:33 Completed 2/03/22, 11:33 Completed 2/03/22, 11:33 Completed (achieved pass grade) 9/03/22, 13:43 9/03/22, 13:43 I was not able to understand if this behavior is normal or did we setup something wrong in the system. Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: How often is the Cron job running to course completion? Completion marks as started Calculate regular completion data Kind Regards
Comment 2: Thanks for your reply. The cron was set up to run every hour (server runs on Microsoft IIS ) now it has been lowered to 5 minutes, if this was the reason it would fix the next sessions but i need to find a way to force a check on the one s that have been already submitted . i do not want to mislead anyone but what I also noticed is that the date format between the two report looks different US format for the activity completion and Italian format for the course completion. My (not so) educated guess is that one reads the server timings and the other one the user PC timings if this is the case how could i solve it?.
Comment 3: Hi, I have a similar problem to yours, in my case, the users completed the course weeks ago, however, the LMS decided to update all the completion times and now all activities and course completion time in the "Course completion report" do not match. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=432911 Regards,
Comment 4: Changing the cron scheduling to 5 minutes actually solved the issue for us, the new students who taken the course were tracked properly with of course 5 minutes of timing resolution that is acceptable for us even if we still need to find a way fix old attempts ( i am aware this might not be possible). Basically to my understanding the activity progress is instantaneous while the completion runs at scheduled intervals. That 's why i saw the same timing in the completion reports on most of the activity they actually match the previous settings and actually we did not notice that the cron was not running before the first settings tweak. Our systems runs on MariaDB .
Comment 5: Exactly so. Cron sets the course completion times when it runs its process. Another important thing to remember is that if a Teacher unlocks the course completions for any reason, usually to change the completion criteria, then all the previous completion times for the users are deleted. When cron runs next, it will recalculate those completions and give all those users NEW completion times. This new time may be days, months, or even years after the time the user actually completed the course.
Comment 6: thanks for the reply, actually is ok if the user losts all completion data (of  course if the affected student has to retake the course). We actually need the completion timing to be as much as possible near to the activity tracking because we have some courses that need to be validated by state officers (specifically the ones regarding the worker safety) so we need to show evidence of the time spent on each section. Is it possible to erase completion data manual for a student that needs to retake a course? (for instance if the person volunteered to test it but the final version is different) Many thanks in advance
Comment 7: Correct, I think in my case ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=432911 ) I am experiencing exactly the same as this other ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=406113 ) where the completion dates were changed with apparent no reason, I do also have a scorm and this has happen only to one course. I checked the course logs and course completion or activity completion has not been updated/changed. After the dates were changed I have a mess in the course; Activity completion and Course completion times for activities do not match ( I understand course completion time is created with a cron Job, which in my case runs every min, but I thought the " Course completion " would take the activities completion times from " mdl_course_modules_completion ", but this is not the case). If I update mdl_course_completions.timecompleted , it will update the course completion time, but the activities completion time in the " Course completion " report are still showing the old date, which does not even match the " Activity report " completion times. I wonder where do the " Completion report " takes the completion times for the activities. I am preparing a query to update mdl_course_completions.timecompleted based on the "first" completion event shown in the course logs ( mdl_logstore_standard_log ). Regards,
Comment 8: Hi, To your question about erase/reset completion data for a student, I think there is no easy way to do this other than modifying the database directly. You may want to take a look at this -> https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=369001 Regards,
Comment 9: If all you need to do is reset activity completion dates or some of the manual settings in the course completion (eg Manual approval by role), any teacher can do that in the Activity completion report or in the Course completion report, respectively. Just un check the varioius activity completion box. If you need to do more than that, such as reset other criteria, there is currently not an easy way to do that. The Course Recompletion plugin that Adolfo mentions is excellent, but it is based on a schedule and only works on users that have completed the course already, so that they could retake it with a clean slate. You can't manually choose which user's completion data to delete using it.
Comment 10: By the way, what I have said here is only one particular use case. Actually, the course completion calculates do often try to save the times according to one of the criteria for the course completion, including grabbing the latest activity completion. If you are using only activity completion criteria, it usually does this - from what I have seen. So, sometimes the course completion data is the same as the most recent activity completion date. But there's a lot of other possible criteria too. It saves most of those times in a special table for things that otherwise don't have dates (course_completion_crit_comp). Exactly which dates it grabs for this this and when it uses the cron time, it a bit of a mystery as Adolfo says above. If someone figures it all out, I hope they post it here.
Comment 11: Also, if you have SQL Reporting ability you can use some of the queries I have in the Ad-hoc reports page which show the details for user activity completions including the exact times for each activity: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#User_activity_completions_with_dates
Comment 12: As far as I know, and I could be wrong, the activity completion will be set at the date/time the actual activity was completed. The course completion is set at the date /time the cron job ran, and evaluated the student's activity completions as meeting the course completion criteria. Therefore, the activities may complete at different times to the course, and if Cron is running every ten minutes or so then it will be later than the activity completion settings by around that time. However, it could be very different if the completion criteria has been adjusted manually - unlocked, and reset, for example. In this case, the course completion will be evaluated once you've saved the new settings, and all the data relating to completions prior to that will be lost (in the course completion, at least). The activity completion data will not change, so you could end up with all activities completing way before the course is complete, if the course completion was later unlocked and changed. If you do not unlock course completion and it is not showing a date/time close to when all activities or requirements are met, then check your Cron jobs. It's possible that Cron is set to run at a different time to the default, or that it is not running at all...
Comment 13: Thanks Hal, I do think you are right in all you mentioned, in my case, the course completion was not changed and the cron job is running every 1 minute. We have seen this problem when we have courses with a large number of users (+5000). For far it has happened twice and we do not know why. I opened this thread -> https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=432979 Thanks,

Post title: Participation Report with Quiz
Post description: We have been using the Participation report for many years with a variety of activity types. Our teachers use it to bulk contact students who have not completed a particular activity. When using the participation report for a quiz and selecting 'Post' for actions, We assumed that "No" meant students have not completed the quiz and 'Yes' meant that they have completed it. Recently I have noticed our assumptions are incorrect. I ran some tests. "No" means they have not yet viewed the quiz. 'Yes (1)' seems to show that they have viewed a quiz, 'Yes (2)' means they have viewed and attempted it, while 'Yes (3)' shows they have completed the quiz. Higher numbers, like 'Yes (5)' and 'Yes (7)' seem to show that students have completed multiple attempts. It seems like a variety of actions count as posts. Can anyone confirm the same experience?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I tested this again this morning to confirm which actions are considered 'posts' by the Participation report when a student takes a quiz. Here is what I got. Open quiz - Yes (1) Quiz Attempt - Yes (2) Submit all and finish - Yes (3) Re-attempt quiz - Yes (4) Submit all and finish - Yes (5) I have to admit that I am bummed about this issue. The Participation report is not as usable as I formally presumed, at least not for quizzes. **I also tested the Assignment activity and this works as expected. Assignment submitted - Yes

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to calculate the Moodle's prediction models?
Post description: Hi all, I am wondering if anyone know how to calculate the Moodle prediction models, as I am looking to compare them with some others has been created out side of Moodle. I know that I could decoded from the Moodle code but not sure, I post this subject here hoping that some one already worked on them before. Regards Mo
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There's a wiki page here that describes it at a high level: https://docs.moodle.org/en/Students_at_risk_of_dropping_out
Comment 2: Thanks Dan, I am looking for how the data has been extracted form Moodle's DB and what type of calculations the data has before feeding the machine learning algorithm with that data.  I was thinking to examine the models externally. Regards Mo
Comment 3: right - so first you need to read that doc linked above - and see how each activity is broken down into cognitive and social indicators - how those indicators are calculated is covered at a high level in that doc. Each activity in moodle defines it's own indicator classes eg here's the social breadth one for the forum activity: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/forum/classes/analytics/indicator/social_breadth.php Which basically uses the community of inquiry class here: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/analytics/classes/local/indicator/community_of_inquiry_activity.php The values calculated by Moodle for these indicators are stored in the mdl_analytics_indicator_calc table and then collected to be sent to the machine learning mode - to understand the indicator_calc table data you should also understand Moodle's " context " concept so that you can match the records in this table to a user.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ad hoc reports: Pivoting tables to meet this specific need
Post description: Hi everyone, can anyone help me figure out how to pivot data in an Ad Hoc report's SQL query? The examples of pivot statements available online seem straightforward enough, but I'm not able to make it fit my current use case. Here's what I'm attempting to do My query so far is: 
```text
SELECT <fields> 
FROM {user} u INNER JOIN {course_completions} cc ON u.id = cc.userid
INNER JOIN {course} c ON c.id = cc.course 
WHERE c.id in (330, 442)
```
 This gives me a list of every user completion on these specific two courses. Now, I'd like to have the Activity/Module completions (mdl_course_modules and mdl_course_modules_completion) but a JOIN would just create like 10+ rows where I want just one. What I want to do is pivot the data from these two tables, and have it appear as columns, so that each module completion has its own column, and one user's course completion is limited to one row.
Does anyone have any leads on how to do this, or a simple example of pivoting those tables to match my needs? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: One way to do it is using the function GROUP_CONCAT. You can find some examples of that in the Ad-hoc contributed reports page if you search the page. But if you have a lot of data to put into a single column, it can become unwieldy pretty quickly. I use this method if there are only a few things to put into the column. Otherwise, I export the full data and then do pivots in a spreadsheet.
Comment 2: This works I'd love to have it split up between columns, as a pivot would do (and my use case makes it more helpful to pivot it before export, since the end user might not know how to), but for now this is perfectly usable. Thanks!
Comment 3: Vedant, Most welcome. Also, if using GROUP_CONCAT be aware that the default size for it is small, only 1024 bytes. You may need more room for the combined text. See this discussion on that issue and how to solve it.
Comment 4: I'll definitely have a look at that, thanks!
Comment 5: For anyone reading this forum discussion afterwards, here's what I ended up doing 
```text
    MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1000 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Quiz Chapter 1",
    MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1709 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Chapter 2 E-learning",
    MIN(CASE m.id WHEN 1234 THEN IFNULL(mc.completionstate, 0) END) "Quiz Chapter 2",
```
 
```text
    ...
```
 
```text
    GROUP BY u.id, c.id
```
 Where: m.id is the ID of a module you want to track in each column mc.completionstate is the completionstate of that module for a specific user, ie the data that goes under each column The string at the end is the column name desired u.id is the user id c.id is the course id The results are as follows: user id other user or course info quiz chapter 1 chapter 2 e-learning quiz chapter 2 200 ... 2 1 2 Just as a note, null & 0 is incomplete, 1 is complete, 2 is complete&passed, 3 is complete&failed. Check the moodle schema docs for more info if needed
Comment 6: Vedant, I am just wondering why you do not use the Activity Completion Report that already exist in Moodle? you can access it by navigating to course settings >> More >>Reports >> Activity completion. I think it is the same unless I missed something of your above requirements. Let me know what do you think, please. Regards Mo
Comment 7: Hi Motasem, It's exactly the same, but the Activity Completion report only shows for one course at a time, plus we need to navigate into the course whenever we need the report. This is a bit more scalable (we currently have 3 similar courses running to the same report) and allows for automation (we can run it into Power BI) I hope that makes sense, happy to answer any further questions. Cheers!
Comment 8: Thanks Vedant, That is defiantly make sense. But the code you shared above using CASE statement can work in your case having three different courses. What about if you need to have this report for a school, which have many courses and the modules or activities could be change over the time, and each year some updates will be on most of the courses. I found this example online but not sure yet if that will help. I will try it when I get some time and let you know. There is another thing I would suggest, to create a macro to pivot the table in Excel or google sheet. Or automate the pivoting procedure in your data warehouse, I think that possible too. Regards Mo
Comment 9: Firstly, yes, this report isn't entirely scalable. We'd need to go in and manually find the new module numbers and add them in. However I do prefer this to any of the previous solutions I've investigated, but I'm open to hearing if there's any better ones. Secondly, I'm not an sql expert by any means, but I do believe that the PIVOT function is supposed to aggregate items, such as the sum or count of certain values (as opposed to this, which is just listing one value, if that makes sense) And finally, we could definitely pivot using Power BI or Excel, that would work. But this report also has the benefit of being readable if one of our instructors needs to go in and check on anything. Ultimately though I think the question of which approach is better would vary. Maybe exporting a list of module completions separately and manipulating it in your end software would work better for you. Cheers!

Post description: Hi all, I'm trying to create a report which shows: All the students in the current course The groups those students belong to Whether or not the students have completed the course Several of the students' custom profile fields The output I'm trying to get is something like: Desired output Username Country Custom profile field 1 (Organisation Type) Custom profile field 2 (Role Type) Course Group Completed (Y/N) student1 UK Research institute Scientist Pest Management CABI Y student1 UK Research institute Scientist Pest Management Researchers Y student2 FR Government body Trainer Pest Management Researchers N Actual output Username Country Custom profile field 1 (Organisation Type) Custom profile field 2 (Role Type) Course Group Completed (Y/N) student1 UK Research institute Scientist Pest Management CABI Y student1 UK Research institute Scientist Pest Management Researchers Y student1 UK Research institute Scientist Pest Management Researchers Y student2 FR Government body Trainer Pest Management Researchers Y I'm using the Certificate Issued (custom certificate plugin) as a proxy for completion, but happy to go with an alternative method. A student may be in more than one group. You can see in the actual output that I'm ending up with: Duplicate lines Everyone is showing as completed The query I'm working with is shown below: 
```text
SELECT c.shortname AS Course, 
u.u
sername AS 'Username', u.country AS 'Country', uid.data AS 'Organisation Type', uir.data AS 'Role Type', g.name AS Groupname,
```
 
```text
	CASE WHEN i.userid IS NOT NULL 
# Should test to see whether the student has a certificate or not


	THEN 'Yes'


	ELSE "No"


	END


	AS "Has certificate"


FROM prefix_course AS c


# Select the certificate
```
 Any help gratefully received! Thanks, Mark

Comment 1: Off the top of my head, I think this issue appears to be that you are testing for a NULL for the Custom Certificate completion but also are using an INNER JOIN to join to the certificate issues. Comment 3: Did you try changing both the cert tables to left joins?
Comment 4: Hi Mark, I think Randy meant to check this part of the code, CASE WHEN i.userid IS NOT NULL # Should test to see whether the student has a certificate or not THEN 'Yes' ELSE "No" END AS "Has certificate" It is going to be always yes because the userid will not be null, you need to change this condition. I think the condition should be related to customcert or customcert_issue, you can try this CASE WHEN i.userid = u.id # because the customcert_issues is the table which Stores each issue of a customcert THEN 'Yes' ELSE "No" END AS "Has certificate" I hope that will help. Regards Mo

Post title: Analytics -- the option to receive emails or not
Post description: Hi all We enabled analytics for this first time (after reading the documentation and watching the explanatory video) and hundreds of our teachers were flooded with collectively >1,000 insight emails. Clearly, this is not ideal. The concept of analytics is a good one. However, there needs to be options and control over how these insights are gathered and distributed. For example, in one circumstance, I may desire site administrators to manually view insights reports periodically. In other circumstances, I may choose that teachers receive email notifications for given models. A blanket "email every teacher in every circumstance", with no ability to set this preference against each model is a poorly conceived approach, and has led to us needing to disable the whole thing. This is a shame as we are missing out on useful information. Please consider introducing emails as an *option* for analytics. Kind Regards Lee Cujes
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lee, On this page: Site administration → Messaging → (Default) Notification settings You have the following notification setting: "Insights generated by prediction models" You can change the defaults and make it an "Opt in" thing - setting the default so users won't get notifications with insights, and if a user wants such insights, he can set its own notification settings in the preferences.
Comment 2: Thank you Acqua, that's the setting we were looking for. For future enhancements to Analytics, it would be good if within the Analytics settings page itself, it referenced (or directly accessed) this email setting.
Comment 3: Lee, It would be great if you can share with us your experience by enabling the Analytics. Did you test the accuracy? is it cause any load on the server ? did they take time to delver insights or predictions? especially the straggling student model. Regards Mo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Logs = prior to six months ago?
Post description: We have a course taught in the Spring of 2021 (which hasn't been touched since then). I need to retrieve some data regarding one student with a late grade dispute, but the reports options in Moodle only retrieve data from the last six months. Is there a way to go back further? I have a course backup from June 2021; if I restore that backup, would I get the historical course reports? Thanks in advance for any insight... Lisa
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: When you say the "report option in Moodle only retrieves data from the last six months" do you mean that your site is set to truncate the logs after 6 months? (In Site admin > Plugins > Logging > Standard logs :: Keep logs for. ). If so then that makes sense as you would only see the last six months of dates in the pull down menu in Reports > Logs to choose a date. If that is what is happening, then that old data is no longer in the database . If you did a course backup and you checked the "Include course logs" option, then when you restore the course it will restore all those log entries as well with their original dates and times. (If the backup did not include those course logs, then there are no old logs to restore.) _However_, the very next time the site runs the task to truncate the logs older than 6 months, it will then delete all those restored entries with those dates older than 6 months. By default his task runs once a day. So, if you need to view those old dates for a while, then you might consider temporarily setting the Logs not to delete, until you can get that old data out and save it, then set it back to truncate at 6 months.

Post title: Log reports frequently "The user with id 'X' changed the password of the user with id 'X'. (Workaround found)
Post description: After bulk importing a user list I found the logfile full of messages: 1850 of this type in under a day. My research led to the following: Accidently two user were created where both Mail addresses contained a german character, the sz (ẞ) symbol. Whereas I am confident that the creation with "umlaut" (e.g. ae, ä) failed at import the sz got through. After disabling a user the reporting stopped immediately. I deleted the users and created them new with their correct address and everything is fine. Maybe theses other entries are related: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=409685 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=410752 Best Bernhard

Post title: Only show certain activities on course completion report for the teacher
Post description: I am at a loss. I am trying to obtain a course completion report that only shows the activities that count towards the final grade of the students. But not all activities are scored. Some are purely for self-evaluation, others count for the final grade. Students need to be able to track their progress / completion of all of the activities (self-evaluation + graded). But I as a teacher wanta report showing only the completion of the graded activities. When I choose "do not indicate activity completion" on the activities that are ther for self-evaluation purposes, they disappeer from th completion report I sees (which is what I want), but then students are no longer able to sees if they have completed that self-assessment or not (and I do not want that to happen). Please tell me how I can let Moodle know which activities to show on the activity completion report a teacher can generate, without taking away the possibility of students to track all their activity completions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Vaya. There are two reports - a report for Activity completion and a report for course completion as in the Course completion status block You can indicate activity completion for all activities students need to do but you can select only the ones they have to do that count towards their final grade by selecting them for course completion - and then only those will appear in the course completion report for example in the Course completion status block . There is more information in the documentation Using Course completion

Post description: I am trying to create a data lake using data from 20-25 independently hosted moodle systems on the same network. I cannot access the backend of these systems. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As an alternative to csv file manual download , the admin can also run a SQL query from the front end and have it automatically emailed by using the Ad-hoc database queries plugin. If you can have them emailed into the same email box, you may be able to process it from there. At least you will have gotten the data out of Moodle at that point. The other option would be using the web access API, which could at least be set up by the admin without needing any back end access. If you wanted to code it that way instead of via SQL.

Comment 3: You should start with this page: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Web_services_API

Post title: course administration > course completion menu item
Post description: Hi. Apologies if this is not the correct place to post this query (I'm new to using this site so any help appreciated). We have a role setup for our administration team. The role is based on the manager role and has the ability to edit a course. We have restricted the course administration block menu  and role function so that the administration team user can edit course content, maintain users (e.g. ability to enrol users, use groups etc) and access the reports only. We have upgraded to 3.9.9 from 3.5. Since the upgrade the administration team role now has access to the course administration block > course completion > default activity completion and the bulk edit activity completion settings. Enable completion tracking is enabled on the site and we use the it to enable our learners to manually complete activities . Is there a permission that we can update that will remove the role's access to the course administration > course completion menu item. Look forward to hearing from you. Kind regards. Paul
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you tried setting Course " View course completion report" (report/completion:view ) to Prohibit? It is set to Allow by default for Manager, Teacher, and Non-editing Teacher roles.
Comment 2: Hi Randy, thanks for the post. I've tried that and it removes the report which we want to keep - but does not remove the course completion menu item. Kind regards. Paul
Comment 3: Ah, well, I don't know if there is a way to block the access specifically to the Course admin > Course completion. It seems to be included in the permission for Update course (moodle/course:update). The two tabs for the activities are controlled by the permission /course:manageactivities. In /course/completion.php it checks for both of these: if the user does not have course update but does have the ability to manageactivities, it will redirect them and let them see those two tabs for the bulk and default activities, otherwise they see and can set all three. It only blocks it if the user lacks both those permissions. So, it seems if the user has either those permissions, they can see the Course Completion menu.

Post title: Moodle Forum Analytics
Post description: Hello! Just brainstorming here: The Moodle Association of Japan moved the reporting about forums forward via the MUA a few release cycles ago. Now, uses have access to a "Summary Report" and users can also "Export" raw forum data for analysis. These are two positives. However, working with these tools and other forum analysis tools, we have discovered things really bog down when the data grows big. Checking relationships between replies (for example) and calculating the depth of replies (for another example) for each user, each group, each grouping , and even analyzing "discussion post by discussion post" gets increasingly complex and taxing on system resources. Would there be any value or benefit in designing (for Moodle) a kind of "Report Caching" system that would periodically update selected tables with summarized data for display? What I mean is that a user chooses the report they want to "cache" and then that report gets run using the specified criteria once every cron cycle (as a scheduled task -- for example -- hourly). Then the data is slowly populated in the background and made available through a single table read and display when the user accesses the report. If there already exists such a system (I'm not talking about configurable reports which require regular users to have a deeper knowledge of SQL ), I'd be interested in learning more about it. If such a system doesn't exist, I suggest (with LA becoming more and more prominent) that Moodle should begin planning one. What do others think?

Post title: Total Course Logs
Post description: Hi all, I use Course Logs very often for monthly reports and it would be handy to download the logs for every course at once with a "course name" column or such (filtered by the current month), save having to individually download every course log every month. Is there any possible way to do this via configurable reports? I'm not new to SQL but I can't find any table or relationship pertaining to the course logs. Diolch (Thank you)!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is no separate table for that. All logs are in the main table mdl_logstore_standard_log which has a column for course called courseid. All you need to do is filter on that column to limit it to specific courses. You will find several examples of how to use this in the Ad-hoc contributed reports page, eg https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports#Total_activity_per_course.2C_per_unique_user_on_the_last_24h .

Comment 1: Ok, so I got this to work by cacheing the form data.
Comment 2: Same issue here. How did you cache the form data?
Comment 3: Sorry Andres, I am out of the office, I will post my code Tuesday or Wednesday
Comment 4: Ok, so in my report index.php file I call my options form,
then I have this code: // Define variables. if ($id) { $report =
$DB->get_record('local_customreports', array('id' => $id)); $toform = new
StdClass(); $queryparams =
unserialize($report->queryparams); foreach
($queryparams as $param => $value) { $toform->{$param} = $value; } $courseids =
$queryparams['course']; $requestedcohort =
$queryparams['cohort']; $completionstatus
= $queryparams['completionstatus']; $datefrom =
$queryparams['datefrom']; $dateto =
$queryparams['dateto']; if
(!empty($queryparams['coloptions'])) { $profieldids =
array_keys($queryparams['coloptions']); } $cachedata = ''; $mform->set_data($toform); } else { $cache = cache::make_from_params(cache_store::MODE_SESSION,
'report_trainingsummary', 'search'); if ($cachedata =
$cache->get('data')) { // Cache form
submission so that it is preserved while paging through the report. $mform->set_data($cachedata); } } // Form has been submitted or we have cached data. $data = ($mform->is_submitted() ? $mform->get_data() :
fullclone($cachedata)); if ($data) { if
(!empty($data->course)) { $courseids =
$data->course; } if
(!empty($data->cohort)) { $requestedcohort =
$data->cohort; } if
(!empty($data->completionstatus)) { $completionstatus
= $data->completionstatus; } if
(!empty($data->datefrom)) { $datefrom =
$data->datefrom; } if
(!empty($data->dateto)) { $dateto =
$data->dateto; } if
(!empty($data->coloptions)) { $profieldids =
array_keys($data->coloptions); } unset($data->submitbutton); $cache->set('data', $data); } Hope this helps!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Completed course report
Post description: I am trying to generate a report and later have the user autogenerate within the course and download as CSV, a list of users that have completed a course given it's short name and date of completion. If there isn't an easy way out of the box, does anyone have a similar SQL query I can run?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I created this query to test: SELECT dbo.mdl_user.username, dbo.mdl_user_info_data.data AS EmployeeNum, dbo.mdl_user.firstname, dbo.mdl_user.lastname, dbo.mdl_course.shortname, dbo.mdl_course.fullname, DATEADD(S, dbo.mdl_course_completions.timeenrolled, '1970-01-01') AS EnrolledDate, DATEADD(S, dbo.mdl_course_completions.timestarted, '1970-01-01') AS StartedDate, DATEADD(S, dbo.mdl_course_completions.timecompleted, '1970-01-01') AS CompletedDate FROM dbo.mdl_user_info_data RIGHT OUTER JOIN dbo.mdl_user ON dbo.mdl_user_info_data.userid = dbo.mdl_user.id RIGHT OUTER JOIN dbo.mdl_course RIGHT OUTER JOIN dbo.mdl_course_completions ON dbo.mdl_course.id = dbo.mdl_course_completions.course ON dbo.mdl_user.id = dbo.mdl_course_completions.userid WHERE (dbo.mdl_course_completions.timecompleted IS NOT NULL) AND (dbo.mdl_user_info_data.fieldid = 1)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Unwanted insights emails from hidden courses
Post description: Teachers are complaining about receiving insights emails from hidden courses via the "Students who have not accessed the course recently" analytics model. We have many instances of hidden courses with students enrolments. This is a deliberate choice, not a mistake, as many Teachers make use of meta-link enrolments and teach courses that draw enrolments from these hidden courses. Is there a way we can stop models from generating insights for hidden courses? I see that hidden courses are not included in the "Students at risk of dropping out" model, but it does not appear to be the case for the "not accessed" models. Or have I missed something here?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thanks Heli for your comment. I think you're right and you found a bug. Hidden courses were added to 'Invalid site element' list in MDL-66806 that affects "Students at risk of dropping out" and some other models, but not "Students who have not accessed the course recently" model. So I've created MDL-71274 issue to fix it. I encourage you to watch, vote or comment on it to add as many information as you can. Thanks for your help and support!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Activities assigned to specific groups
Post description: I am trying to write a sql query that shows activities that have been assigned to specific groups.  Where are these group assignments stored?  I can see how a particular course gets assigned to a group(s), but not a particular activity.  (We primarily use Questionnaires).
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Katie Activities are not assigned groups specifically. If you set them to use Groups in their settings, either Separate or Visible, they simply uses the groups as defined at the course level. (Except Assignment, which is something else.) You will find the group settings for each activity in the course_modules table. Now, if you are using Access restrictions to restrict an activity to a specific group, then that is also in the course_modules table in the column called "availability". Unfortunately, it is a mess: it is not properly normalized at all and so you will have to parse out the string to find the group. For example: {"op":"&","c":[{"type":"group","id":93}],"showc":[true]} which tells you this activity is restricted by group to the group with id 93.
Comment 2: Thank you for the help. Yes, it does look like I need to figure out the logic of the availability field on course_modules. My users love the out of the box activity completion report, but want it modified so that when an activity is not visible to members of certain groups, the activity either does display on the report or has a status of "not required". Oh how I wish there was an easy way to do this! I'll figure it out, but it's going to be painful! Thanks again!
Comment 3: Katie, Oh, I hear you. A pox upon all devs who don't normalize their data.
Comment 4: Randy, That's a good suggestion regarding working in a development system.  I suppose I am fortunate in that the users really want this to work to the point were are willing to keep their restrictions pretty simple.  Still, even if it was just groups with the occasional cohort restriction, it's a pain. I'm very new to moodle and got dragged into this because SQL is my thing.  Can you tell me if it is possible to create views that you can use on custom reports?  With all the Cases and substrings, views would make this easier! Thanks again for all the help! Katie
Comment 5: Katie, Ah, are you using Config reports and/or the Ad-hoc queries plugins? Those are both read only basically, though Config Reports will let you use some basic things like UPDATE if you turn off the "SQL Security" in its plugin settings. But it can't create things like views or temp tables and so forth. However, if you create views another way, you can certainly use those in your queries, as long as the views are in the same moodle db (because the plugins run as the Moodle user set up for that db and that should be the only one it has access to.). A common and useful view is one for user firstname and lastname. I usually do one for course completions because its a popular request. Also, if your find yourself having to do reports from the logs, a view can dramatically speed things up, for instance if you have to do a query for "last time a student entered their courses". If you are new to Moodle then perhaps these things may help: - Do you have Adminer installed? https://moodle.org/plugins/local_adminer . Everyone has their favorite tools, but this one is very handy because it is right there in Moodle. - I assume you are aware of the Ad-hoc contributed queries page: https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/ad-hoc_contributed_reports but if not, it's a mismash but I borrow from it all the time. - Finally, most of the questions about queries are posted over in the forum for the Configurable Reports plugin rather than here, mostly because of history I suppose, but most of the SQL people hang out there: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=7979 Randy

Comment 5: I don't know exactly the details of how this works. What I understand is that the sesskey is stored with the other session data in in the session cache using memcached, by default anyway. ( https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/Session_handling ). If it is not calculated each time from the sessionid in some way - and according to that document they don't seem to be related - then I don't think it is in the database , unless you have set Session handling > Use database for session information to On in your settings. Forum Post: 
Post title: New plugin Learning Object Relation Discovery (LORD)
Post description: The Learning Object Relation Discovery (LORD) plugin is now available from the plugins directory ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_lord ). This plugin extracts the text content from the learning activities in a course and uses that content to compare the activities against each other, producing a similarity score between each pair of activities. The comparison uses an online sentence similarity calculator ( https://ws-nlp.vipresearch.ca/ ) to determine the similarity values. The similarity calculator uses WordNet, so is currently limited to the English language, but support for Hindi and French are planned for later in 2021. The comparison process runs as a background task and can take some time to complete. Once all the similarity values are known between all the learning objects, the learning object graph (LOG) can be made. A network graph is created where the nodes are the learning objects from the course and the similarity values between objects is used to position the nodes, grouping learning objects with similar content. This plugin can be used by itself to examine the similarity between learning activities and also integrates with the Behaviour Analytics plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_behaviour ). The Behaviour Analytics plugin uses a network graph of learning objects to cluster students according to their behaviour patterns, but the graph nodes are grouped by section and require manual arrangement. The LORD plugin is designed to automatically configure the graph so that it does not have to be manually configured, which should produce better clustering.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Sounds like a tough position you're in! - If your supervisor isn't giving you any support you may just need to look at a different project. To run the training of the analytics you will need a copy of a moodle database with a number of courses and historical logs - ideally the courses will have start and end dates set in the table already, however you can run some scripts that will set/guess the end-date of some of the courses. The "prediction" process currently requires active logs - or a way to generate user activity after the training process has been run (which is not all that easy to do on a testing site.) There is a research data set here which contains a logsstore and user data export, https://research.moodle.org/158/ But - it doesn't contain the course table in that data set which is needed for the analytics processes - you might be able to fake it by generating a bunch of courses that correspond to the courseid in the logstore table - if you're lucky it might even just be one course in that data-set but I haven't looked at using it myself. Forum Post: 
Post title: New plugin Behaviour Analytics
Post description: Greetings fellow Moodlers, The Behaviour Analytics block plugin ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_behaviour ) has recently been released in the Moodle plugin directory. This plugin provides teachers with a visualization of their students' learning behaviour patterns. Learning modules from a course are used as nodes in a network graph, which can be arbitrarily positioned. Student accesses to the modules create links between the nodes and become the students' behaviour pattern. It is possible to compare the learning patterns of students to see their similarities and differences for various time slices. The plugin also allows students to be clustered according to their behaviour patterns. Each student has a unique pattern that is compressed to a single point, then these student centroid points can be clustered to group students. Clusters of students may have common learning behaviours that can be viewed by hovering over a cluster centroid. It is also possible to annotate the students and clusters during the clustering stage. Currently, the VIP Research Group at Athabasca University ( https://vipresearchgroup.ca/ ) are also developing the LORD (learning Object Relation Discovery) Moodle plugin. The LORD plugin uses WordNet and Natural Language Processing to measure the similarity between two learning objects (activity modules). The similarities are used to automatically position the Learning Object Graph (LOG) nodes, rather than using manual positioning. Presently, only the English language is supported, but there are plans to support French and Hindi next year (2021). The LORD plugin has not yet been released to the Moodle plugin directory, but is available on GitHub ( https://github.com/Behaviour-Analytics/moodle-block_lord ). There is also a new version of Behaviour Analytics plugin available ( https://studyguide.athabascau.ca/networkgraph/download.php ) that is designed to integrate with LORD. Both LORD and the new Behaviour Analytics will get submitted to the Moodle plugin directory later this year.

Post title: Equivalent postgresql code
Post description: Hi all. Sorry if this looks like a newbie problem, because I am a newbie to Moodle and SQL in general. I saw this contributed SQL report written in some SQL DBMS. Now I learned that our Moodle installation uses postgresql and this code doesn't work. 
```text
SELECT 
l.id, 
l.timecreated, 
DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated),'%d-%m-%Y') AS dTime,

@prevtime := (SELECT MAX(timecreated) FROM mdl_logstore_standard_log 
		WHERE userid = %%USERID%% AND id < l.id ORDER BY id ASC LIMIT 1) AS prev_time,

IF (l.timecreated - @prevtime < 7200, @delta := @delta + (l.timecreated-@prevtime),0) AS sumtime,

l.timecreated-@prevtime AS delta,
"User" AS TYPE



FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log AS l, 
(SELECT @delta := 0) AS s_init 


 # CHANGE UserID

WHERE l.userid = %%USERID%% AND l.courseid = %%COURSEID%%

%%FILTER_STARTTIME:l.timecreated:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:l.timecreated:<%%
```

Forum Post: 
Post title: Analytics in the news
Post description: Here's a thread where any of us can post news items or articles we've seen about analytics and machine learning. My first contribution: Unintended Consequences and Goodhart’s Law: The importance of using the right metrics https://towardsdatascience.com/unintended-consequences-and-goodharts-law-68d60a94705c "Goodhart’s Law is expressed simply as: “When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.” In other words, when we set one specific goal, people will tend to optimize for that objective regardless of the consequences. " Let's think about how this could affect learning analytics. If we don't choose our targets carefully, participants may optimize their participation too narrowly. Here's a example given in the article: "In school, we are given one objective: maximize our grade. This focus on one number can be detrimental to actual learning. High school seemed like one long series of memorizing content for a test, then promptly forgetting it all so I could stuff my brain full of info for the next one, without any consideration of whether I really knew the concepts. This strategy worked quite well given how success was measured in school, but I doubt it is the best approach for a great education." One of the significant-- and often overlooked-- advantages of learning analytics is their potential to detect hidden or "latent" factors in the learning process , not just predict a learning product . What kinds of processes could we detect that would be less prone to "gaming the system" than a final grade prediction?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Not sure if I am allowed to make contributions, but this caught my eye: What Parents and Teachers Think About Education Data (September 12, 2018) https://dataqualitycampaign.org/resource/what-parents-and-teachers-think-about-education-data/ Personally I am positively surprised at the reported open-mindedness of parents regarding use of data about their children by teachers. On the teacher level, the challenges are reasonable and known, at least I assume as much for members of this community: limited skills, limited time, low prioritization by officials, insufficient development of supporting tools. It also links to a 4-step policy plan to "Make Data work for Students" which at first glance I believe it is compatible with Moodle Learning Analytics approach https://dataqualitycampaign.org/resource/four-policy-priorities-make-data-work-students/ Full disclosure, I do not know more about the Data Quality Campaign, its motives, nor its potential conflicts of interests than what shows on its website. It is largely funded by philanthropies from wealthy people and corporations. https://dataqualitycampaign.org/who-we-are/
Comment 2: I know this is a bit of an old thread, but just adding a link to our press release which includes some links to a tv and radio interview from Canterbury University who are using Moodle Analytics with Tensorflow https://www.catalyst.net.nz/news/catalyst-and-university-canterbury-use-ai-better-support-students I presented on this at the online Moodlemoot - keep an eye out for the recordings which should be publicly accessible in a month or so.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Users in current course with group and enrolment method
Post description: Hi there, I'm trying to create a report which shows a list of all the people enrolled in a course, along with their groups and enrolment methods. Having multiple lines per user is fine. I just want to create a CSV file that I can then analyse further. Here's what I've got so far. It's returning multiple lines per user, but isn't returning any lines where Group is Null. 
```text
SELECT
Enrolments.CourseName,
Enrolments.EnrolledUserID,
Enrolments.UserEmail,
Enrolments.UserName,
Enrolments.UserCountry,
g.name AS GroupName,
Enrolments.enrolID,
Enrolments.EnrolName,
Enrolments.AutoEnrolName

FROM 
(SELECT
 e.id AS EnrolID,
 e.name AS EnrolName,
 e.customchar2 AS AutoEnrolName,
 c1.id AS CourseID1,
 c1.shortname AS CourseName,
 u1.id AS EnrolledUserID,
 u1.email AS UserEmail,
 u1.username AS UserName,
 u1.country AS UserCountry,
 u1.confirmed AS UserConfirmed,
 u1.deleted AS UserDeleted
 
 FROM prefix_user AS u1
 
 LEFT JOIN prefix_user_enrolments AS ue ON u1.id = ue.userid
 LEFT JOIN prefix_enrol AS e ON e.id = ue.enrolid
 LEFT JOIN prefix_course AS c1 ON e.courseid = c1.id

WHERE c1.id = %%COURSEID%% AND u1.email NOT LIKE "%@xxx.org" AND e.enrol NOT LIKE "manual"

) AS Enrolments

LEFT JOIN prefix_groups_members AS m ON Enrolments.EnrolledUserID = m.userid
JOIN prefix_groups AS g ON m.groupid = g.id
JOIN prefix_course AS c ON g.courseid = Enrolments.CourseID1
```
 What I'd like to end up with is a table like this: User Group Enrolment method John Group 1 Self-enrol 1 John Group 2 Self-enrol 1 Fred Group 1 Auto-enrol Anne Self-enrol 2 Many thanks, Mark

Post title: Course Progress Flightpath Report
Post description: I am considering commissioning someone
to produce a new ‘Course Progress Flightpath’ report plugin for Moodle, which would enable teachers to review an individual student’s progress within a course over time as opposed to the 'live snapshot' views which are all that seems to be available currently. My plan is either to sponsor or co-sponsor the project (or possibly contribute to crowdfunding the project if it turns out to be hugely expensive) with the plugin then becoming available in Moodle plugins directory for free. At this stage I'm interested in two things: People's feedback on the attached draft specification (I'm sure there will be lots of things I haven't considered). Any thoughts on who / how to go about finding a developer to cost and complete this project. Please note that I'm conscious this plugin might require significant resources to run on sites with many courses and many users. I've have taken this into account when designing the attached specification, but if anyone has any additional thoughts/suggestions about this area please let me know. If you have any feedback then you can either do so in the forum thread, or by adding comments or tracked changes to the attached specification and uploading it in your reply.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Steve, Overall this looks good. I find the distinction between the activity completions per se and whether they are also in the course completion settings to be interesting. My experience tells me these are almost always set the same, but obviously don't have to be. In any case, there's likely some education to do here for  instructors. I think the section that is missing is the specific capabilities your plugin will need. You mention "roles" several times but it is much better if you first specify which capabilities your plugin will need to have to be added to those roles (or to be available to any custom roles.) It won't work without some sort of checking and it is much better practice (and the common Moodle code practice) to check for specific capabilities and permissions instead of a standard role. This is especially so as you plan to open it up for others to use, and you have no way of knowing how sites may use or adjust roles, but with a permissions based setup, anyone will easily be able to adapt it to their specific setup. Good luck, Randy

Post title: SQL enhance ad hoc requests with roles
Post description: Hello, we've been using some requests from the ad hoc repositery that is a great help, however i encounter some difficulties with roles assignments. Example with a query that retrieve number of created activities count, here is the initial one that works well. SELECT DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(timecreated), "%d-%m-%Y") AS jour,           SUM(if(m.name = 'assign', 1, 0)) AS devoir, SUM(if(m.name = 'quiz', 1, 0)) AS quiz, SUM(if(m.name = 'forum', 1, 0)) AS forum, SUM(if(m.name = 'chat', 1, 0)) AS chat, SUM(if(m.name = 'resource', 1, 0)) AS fichier, SUM(if(m.name = 'folder', 1, 0)) AS dossier FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log log JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.id = log.objectid JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id = cm.module WHERE  action = 'created' Now we are trying to generate same report for teacher and student roles. Using joins on role_assignments table. Here are the new FROM / JOIN part : FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log log JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.id = log.objectid JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id = cm.module JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = log.userid With this we got too much hits, probably initial count multiplied by how many roles has the user. (Am testing on an invisible course where i created a few different activities). Tried also joining context table with context level set to 70 FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log log JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON cm.id = log.objectid JOIN prefix_modules m ON m.id = cm.module JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = log.userid JOIN prefix_context as ctx ON ctx.id = cm.module AND ctx.contextlevel = 70 Also tried to join role assignment and context like this JOIN prefix_role_assignments ra ON ra.userid = log.userid AND ra.context = ctx.instanceid JOIN prefix_context as ctx ON ctx.id = cm.module AND ctx.contextlevel = 70 All of the above returns too many count, usually mutliplied by 16 wich looks like maximum assignments role set on the platform. Using ra.roleid = 1 looks ok but not other roles. Anyone to points me in the right direction ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Cédric, I think what is missing from the role assignments is a connection to the user_enrolment table, which will give you the role inside the course. Connecting the role assignment to the userid in the is giving you too many results just as you say, since it is not being limited to the course where the activities are. The user_enrolment table should limit that. Randy
Comment 2: Hello Randy, thanks a lot for your answer, acutally i did not manage yet to make it. We have a lot of queries to write, will return to that one soon i hope. Thanks for your time.

Post title: Previous predictions deleted when the model changes
Post description: We've had a few times when we want to add a new indicator to an existing model, but this causes all previous predictions to be deleted. I can't see a good reason for this to occur on a minor change to the model - the previous predictions are still "valid" - Is there something I'm missing here?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: From a strict model accuracy point of view, yes, the old predictions are no longer valid. It's impossible for the system to guess whether the indicator you've changed would be "minor". I would recommend making a copy of the model and adding the new indicator there, so your previous training data would not be deleted. You could then evaluate both models and compare them. Best regards, Elizabeth
Comment 2: Thanks Elizabeth - I hear we're you're coming from, but the model doesn't use the previously generated predictions when generating new predictions does it? - so deleting them seems a bit drastic and not really necessary? We are also playing a bit with returning regression scores from tensorflow and wanting to maintain the history of predictions even when the model changes - we might just have to maintain the non-deletion of predictions as a local change.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Learning analytics training-csv file
Post description: Hi, We are evaluating the Students in risk of dropping out model in Moodle 3.8, trying to improve the evaluation accuracy. After after running evaluation process and exporting the training-data  file, we always get the same number of lines in the csv file, regardless of the number of courses/students evaluated. in our case this is 9379 lines , of which 9376 are sample records, divided into 4 ranges that is 2344 samples per range. Our data scientist guy is using the training-data externally in Azure ML framework, in order to evaluate the results. However he is confused of that fact. Can someone elaborate more on the representation of each sample  line in the csv file with relation to the data set used for evaluation? How come this is a fixed number with no correlation to the number of students evaluated? My guess is some kind of a multiplication of indicators with other parameters. Yet, further clarification is most welcomed. Best Regards, Yuval.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Yuval, Is the evaluation process completing? Do you have a log file of its status? Separately, has the model training task completed? Do you have a log file of its status? The evaluation process does not actually populate the training data -- evaluation and training are two separate steps. Training prepares the model for use. Evaluation checks the accuracy of a model by breaking up past data into "training data" and "test data" and uses only the "training data" to train the model, then tests its predictions on the "test data". Because the evaluation process only uses some of the available data to train the model, its results are not what are used to make ongoing predictions. It sounds like your model has looked at 2344 enrolments to train the model. Does this match how many student records you expected for completed enrolments? If not, have you checked the "invalid samples" report to see if there is a problem with your data? For example, if your prior courses don't have start and end dates defined, those courses would not be considered "valid" for training the model. Probably we need clearer displays of the status of models (trained, evaluated, data used, etc.) Proposals you might want to view and vote for in the tracker: Best regards, Elizabeth
Comment 2: Hi Elizabeth, Thank you so much for your detailed answer. All processes were completed successfully. Invalid site elements returns empty report. The last evaluation task I ran was on a single course with less than 1000 students. Before the task was executed I have cleared all courses from the course table (except for this single course), purged all analytics data from the DB (except for the analytics_models table), and deleted model files from moodledata/model folder. I also purged caches. So this was like a fresh installation run on a single course. Yet I got the same figures in the CSV file, as described above. Anyway, I'm guessing this is not an issue that should concern us too much: It's not really a problem, but rather an internal algorithm setup of which we currently do not understand in full. Best regards, Yuval.

Post title: Creating a model to identify students at risk of failing
Post description: Hello, I administer Moodle at a Liberal Arts institution where the majority of discussion and activity happens face-to-face. There are faculty that collect assignments, use forums, and give quizzes in Moodle. There are also many that enter grades for in-class activities into the Moodle grade book. What I am interested in is a way to provide faculty with a warning of students at rick of failing? Is a LA model the best way to go or should I be looking at something that interacts with the grade book to generate a report? Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jon, Moodle learning analytics uses machine learning to make predictions based on data in Moodle. If the majority of interaction at your institution happens face-to-face, you may not have enough data to generate very strong predictions. Assignments, quizzes, and manual grade entries can all help, however. At this time it is not possible to allow teachers to choose whether to see predictions in a model. Teachers can be assigned to a role which sees predictions by a site administrator or manager. You may want to consider a pilot to see how well this would work at your institution.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Retrieving very old log history
Post description: Dear Moodlers, Does anyone know in which table old logs are stored ? I already know that the table prefix_logstore_standard_log contains log history but not older than 2016 ... and I want to get those in 2010 Thanks !!!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That would be the prefix_log table that stored the legacy log, but whether there's anything in it depend on your sites "loglifetime" setting in admin/settings.php?section=logsettinglegacy "This specifies the length of time you want to keep logs about user activity. Logs that are older than this age are automatically deleted. It is best to keep logs as long as possible, in case you need them, but if you have a very busy server and are experiencing performance problems, then you may want to lower the log lifetime. Values lower than 30 are not recommended because statistics may not work properly." If someone set a value for that, then they would have been automatically deleted, in which case your system's yearly backups might have what you need, assuming yearly backups were made and kept? The equivalent for the new standard log loglifetime is at admin/settings.php?section=logsettingstandard

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ad - Hoc Reports Creating User Cumulative Time Spent in Site
Post description: Hallo guys can somebody help me to find out how to create site report of user acces i've found some example but it is spesific on a course here's the code : 
```text
SELECT 
l.id, 
l.timecreated, 
DATE_FORMAT(FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated),'%d-%m-%Y') AS dTime,
@prevtime := (SELECT MAX(timecreated) FROM mdl_logstore_standard_log 
		WHERE userid = %%USERID%% AND id < l.id ORDER BY id ASC LIMIT 1) AS prev_time,
IF (l.timecreated - @prevtime < 7200, @delta := @delta + (l.timecreated-@prevtime),0) AS sumtime,
l.timecreated-@prevtime AS delta,
"User" AS TYPE
 
FROM prefix_logstore_standard_log AS l, 
(SELECT @delta := 0) AS s_init 
# CHANGE UserID
WHERE l.userid = %%USERID%% AND l.courseid = %%COURSEID%%
%%FILTER_STARTTIME:l.timecreated:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:l.timecreated:<%%
```
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Just remove the "l.courseid = %%COURSEID%% condition" and it should give you a sitewide report. 
```text
# CHANGE UserID


- WHERE l.userid = %%USERID%% AND l.courseid = %%COURSEID%%


 + WHERE l.userid = %%USERID%%


 %%FILTER_STARTTIME:l.timecreated:>%% %%FILTER_ENDTIME:l.timecreated:
```
Comment 2: Hello Luis , Thank you for your feedback, i see so when i delete l.userid it wil show sitwide report ?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Relationships between activities
Post description: Here’s a question I was asked recently: Is there a learning analytics tool for Moodle that visualize the data from two activities ? e.g. one student has watched a video 3 times and in Assignment he has the grade 5. So there is a relationship between a material and an assigment. so
I can analyze the data and I give him the appropriate learning unit. Is there any tool for the visualization of two activities. This is an interesting idea.  What would a visualization look like? As an overview, a table showing correlation of views/completion/success could be a good start. If looking at an individual activity, a ranked list of other activities that correlate with success might be useful. Would we want the access to be filtered by recency? Tools like this will be limited by the amount of data they draw on. They won’t be able to make generalizations before students have been active in the course. But this could still be a useful feature. What do others think? Elizabeth
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Elizabeth, I write my doctoral thesis. I am going to develop a new teaching method in order to personalized the student. Only pure data is not interesting. I'm interested in the relationship between data. There are a lot of visual Analytics tools for Business intelligence. I think,  a tool like these tools are interesting for the Learning analytics. with best Regards Sima
Comment 2: Hi Sima, I think this paper might be interesting to you: McKenna, K., Folkestad, J. E., & Moraes, M. C. (2019). Reflections of Visual Form Learning Analytics: Spaced Retrieval Practice Activity. LAK19 Companion Proceedings , 20–25. You might also be interested in looking at Hidden Markov Models, but if you want the models to work across multiple courses, you will need to figure out how to abstract the activity, e.g. [view of file in same section before attempt at quiz ]
Comment 3: thanks a lot Elizabeth. I will read it and I will give you feedback. With best Regards, Sima

Post title: Ad-hoc customized query - multiple course completions that outputs single row for student
Post description: Hello. I'm hoping that someone has done something like this before and can point me in the right direction. For background, we use a course naming scheme that includes a revision level in the course shortname. For example, the "grape" course is the original course. "grape1" is the first update, "grape2" is the second update, and so on. For our reporting, it doesn't matter which "grape" course the student completed, but they must have completed at least one. But if they've completed more than one, I have to report just the latest completion date of all the "grape" courses they've completed. I thought I could take advantage of the course naming by using "grape%", but I get lost quickly from there. Complicating matters (at least for me) is that we have many "fruit" classes that comprise a track of courses that require completion reporting. For example, a rough pseudocode for this reporting would be: If (student has completed any "apple" course, get its latest completion date) AND (if student has completed any "grape" course, get its latest completion date) AND (if student has completed any " pear " course, get its latest completion date) Then (print MAX(course completion dates from each of the "fruit" courses)) and output "Fruit track completed". Only this one date can be shown on any reports. Any and all suggestions are appreciated, Richard

Forum Post: 
Post title: Risks of predictive analytics?
Post description: Here’s a very interesting post by law professor Frank Pasquale, asking if some kinds of analytics should be done at all, given the potential for harm. https://lpeblog.org/2019/11/25/the-second-wave-of-algorithmic-accountability/ We have the best of intentions for predictive learning analytics, but do these predictions improve learning outcomes, even in the best cases? Do we risk prejudicing teachers about the potential of students, or even activating stereotype threat in students themselves? I hope we can show the value to learners and teachers of learning analytics, and minimize the possible harm. I’ve argued in the past that if we have data and analysis methods that could help learners, we may have an ethical obligation to pursue that potential. But I think we probably shouldn’t assume that any predictive learning analytics system would be “better than nothing.” Thoughts?

Post title: Counting User Logins
Post description: Hiya, I have been using the Statistics report to look at logins to our Moodle. I set the time period and Report Type to Logins. The number of Logins seems very high to me. When I run the following SQL query a colleague wrote I get significantly less logins reported. The query looks at usernames and I can change between Staff and students by changing the u.username (staff have alphabetical, students numerical) SELECT COUNT(u.id), u.username, u.firstname, u.lastname FROM mdl_logstore_standard_log l INNER JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id = l.userid WHERE l.component = 'core' AND l.action = 'loggedin' AND u.username REGEXP '^[a-z]+$' AND FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated, '%Y%m%d') >= 20190801 AND FROM_UNIXTIME(l.timecreated, '%Y%m%d') <= 20190831 GROUP BY u.username Is this query OK? Is there a definative way to get this info? Many thanks, Nige.

Post title: How can we combine data from multiple sources to generate insights, e.g. outside of Moodle
Post description: Thoughts?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: What about Google Analytics?
Comment 2: Ideally one would want the activity records stored in a LRS. You can then add any other records (sources) to the LRS. The analytics processor then runs on the full data set in the LRS as opposed to only on Moodle's data.
Comment 3: Google Analytics doesn't make predictions about learning. It is really designed for sales questions, e.g. converting site hits to sales. How many people use a separate LRS (e.g. Learning Locker)? Is there interest in having LRS functionality within Moodle?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Extending the machine learning classifier to allow multi-class discrimination
Post description: Hello, just wanted to announce that as part of google summer of code I will be working on adding multi-class classification to the machine learning backend. This will be done over the course of the summer and will expose functionality from python Tensorflow and the phpml library. The project mainly involves writing the train(), classify() and evaluate_classification() methods for both the php and python backend. The plan is to tackle the php endpoint first which should be done by July and then the python backend by August in order to have everything ready for testing. Everything is expected to be completed by September.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Welcome, Vlad!
Comment 2: Welcome Vlad. The project Vlad will work on will allow us to create predictive models with more than 2 classes. At the moment we only support binary classification (e.g. "is this student at risk?" yes / no). Once this project is completed we will be able to build models like "how often will this user access the course? never / in monthly basis / in weekly basis / in daily basis.
Comment 3: A bit of report on the progress made so far: it turns out the php backend already supported multi-classification out of the box through one vs rest regression implemented in php-ml. I have therefore started working on unit tests that include this aspect. However, it's still work in progress. This is a link to my forked repo and specifically to the branch I made for the php related aspects of adding the multi-classification capabilities: https://github.com/valadhi/moodle/tree/binary_classification_php
Comment 4: Another little progress report. I have now completely handled the php side of the backend. I have written unit tests to check that both training and prediction work well in the case of classification done through php-ml by adding custom test targets and indicators specifically for this case. It's on to the python backend now.
Comment 5: Hello, I have now finished rewriting the python backends. The training and prediction methods were pretty well written and didn't need many changes on the tensorflow graph. The evaluation side was a bit more detailed as it needed some custom handling for different reports related to n_classes > 2. It should be able to plugin perfectly into the existing moodle functionality if you simply specify in the header of the dataset the number of classes and their labels. I still need to make perfectly sure everything is working nicely and perhaps write some automated tests, but it seems to be fine based on my manual testing.
Comment 6: The Google Summer of Code project is now finised and this is the final URL description of the project with all the links to the repositories: https://gist.github.com/valadhi/992b808005a2cf7b7988276aa1533c92 I still want to make some changes regarding the scoring method for model evaluation from MCC to F1 and also hopefully work on identifying and implementing new machine learning uses like new models to use or activity recommendations.
Comment 7: Thanks for your work in GSOC 2019 Vlad. Vlad's GSOC contribution to the Moodle LMS can be found in https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-58992 . The machine learning layer in Moodle 3.8 has now multi-class capabilities, which means that the predictive models run by Moodle are able to classify students in more than 2 classes. An example of this would be a predictive model where students are classified in very low grade , low grade, average grade, high grade and very high grade . Until now we were only able to classify students in 2 classes (e.g. pass / fail). Vlad not only completed his Google Summer of Code project, but also contributed a second improvement to the Moodle LMS: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-66476 , where he modified the algorithm that generates an overall score of a model. It was a pleasure working with you Vlad.

Post title: Learning Analytics Success Stories - an Invitation
Post description: This message: http://tiny.cc/lastories LMSs are incorporating Learning Analytics tools into their core but the uptake by institutions and lecturers is lagging. If we want to convince educators to use analytics tools, we need good stories - not graphs. At Meital/IUCEL (the Israeli Inter-University Center for E-learning https://meital.iucc.ac.il/en/home-3-2/ ), we’re organising a symposium on “Learning Analytics: From Theory to Practice”. At this event, we intend to share success stories from institutions around the world, and analyse them to identify common challenges and solutions. The event will be webcast live and recorded, and the outputs will be shared under a CC-BY licence. SO if you’re - Involved in teaching Had a problem Adopted a learning analytics solution The problem was addressed (to an extent, at least..) Please share your story with us! To make is easy, we’ve prepared a template for you story, in google doc ( https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dgJS4vYEv0Iq_GzCfiJxfN8SpA8ZaV-_bhU7qv9-kM8/ ) or presentation ( https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1wZnS7Jl8DQwc0Y8Kl7DIxBK5dPELlrhvp2uTpAUvVH4/copy ) form (whichever you prefer). Please share this request widely. If you have any comments, questions or suggestions, please direct them at Nadav Kavalerchik nadavkav@gmail.com & Yishay Mor yish@yishaymor.org .

Forum Post: 
Post title: "Not enough course activity between the start and the end of the course" error when training risk of dropping out
Post description: Hi, I have been working with the Moodle analytics models for the past few months. Currently, I am looking at the Student Risk of Dropping out model for my postgrad research. I have successfully trained it with one course but it didn't provide me with enough training data. I, therefore, uploaded a second course but when I try and train with it I get the "Not enough course activity between the start and the end of the course" error. I am not sure why this is because there is a lot of activity on the course. The course has 322 students, 66 different activities and spans over about 3 months. I'm really not sure what the problem is, so any help would be really appreciated! Thanks, Sarah
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sarah, The error you are getting comes from here: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/course/classes/analytics/target/course_dropout.php#L96 . So if your course has 322 students a minimum of 3220 activity logs between the start and the end of the course are required to consider this course valid for training. The purpose of this checking is to ensure that the courses that are used for training have a minimum of activity. We fixed this minimum at 10 activity logs for user. I would check that: The number of activity logs between the start and the end of the course is more than ~3000 The course start and end date are correctly set The start and end of the student enrolments are correctly set You use quarters or quarters accumulative time-splitting methods (the field is renamed to 'analysis interval' in Moodle 3.8) I added this point because the course duration is 3 months and using tenths as the time-splitting method can be a problem. By the way, the other students at risk targets in Moodle 3.7 do not have this "Not enough course activity between the start and the end of the course" restriction.
Comment 2: Thanks, David! I've added this to the Moodle Learning Analytics FAQ .
Comment 3: Thank you! Your response was extremely helpful! I was running it on Moodle 3.7, so not sure why I was getting the error..
